div1.head: THE GUARDIAN
A Play in Four Acts

byline.hi:
by
Booth Tarkington and Harry Leon Wilson

div1.p: The scene is Sorrento, in Southern Italy.

list.item: ACT I.--The terrace of the Hotel Regina Margherita on the cliff at Sorrento. Morning.
ACT III.--An apartment in the hotel. Evening.

list.head: MEN
list.item: Daniel Voorhees Pike (aged thirty-five), of Kokomo, Indiana.
The Grand Duke Vasili Vasilivitch (aged forty-eight).
The Hon. Almeric St. Aubyn (aged twenty-five), son of Lord Hawcastle.
Ribiere (aged thirty), the Grand Duke's secretary.

list.head: WOMEN
list.item: Lady Creech (aged sixty) sister-in-law of Hawcastle.

div2.head: ACT I
div2.stage: Terrace of the Hotel Regina Margherita, on the cliff at Sorrento, overlooking the Bay of Naples.

Back drop shows the bay and semi-circular coast-line, dotted with villages, and Vesuvius gray in the distance. Across the stage at back runs a marble balustrade about three feet high, guarding the edge of the cliff. From up L. C. (meeting upper L. end of railing) the wall of the hotel runs obliquely down to L. where it corners, and runs into foliage wing down L. leaving an entrance there from wings. A door (closed but practicable) in front wall of hotel affords entrance down L. to hotel. This door is of modern Italian style: glass nearly to base, with lace shade. A single step is before the door, which is not on the same level as the doors up L., which are large glass double-doors, forming main entrance from the hotel to the terrace. They are approached by four or five marble steps with railing and small stoop. Windows in Wall L. C. and down L. above door.
Awnings shield all of them. The hotel is of pink and white stucco. R. of stage is a grove, betokened by shrubberies and tree-wings. Two or three small white wicker tea-tables L. Wicker chairs near them. Couple of covered Bath chairs broadly striped with pink and white, up R. near balustrade. Down R. C. is square table laid with white cloth.
Time: Eleven o'clock in the morning; stage bright.
Before the curtain rises mandolines and guitars are heard and the Fisherman's Song, time very rapid and gay, the musicians being off R.

MARIANO, matre d'hotel, is discovered laying the table down R. C. with eggs, coffee and rolls for two. He is a pleasant-faced, elderly man, stout, swarthy, wearing long gray mutton-chop side whiskers; dress clothes, white waistcoat, and black tie. He is annoyed by the music off R.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (as curtain rises, looking off R. crossly).
sp.p: Silenzio!
sp.stage:
MICHELE opens doors from hotel up L. and appears on stoop. He is young, clean-shaven except for a dark mustache, wears a white tie, a blue coat, cut like dress-coat, blue
trousers with red side stripes, brass buttons; his waistcoat is of striped red and blue.

sp.speaker: MICHELE
sp.stage: (speaking over his shoulder to L. but indicating MARIANO with his right hand).
sp.p: Par ici, Monsieur Ribiere, pour le Matre d'hotel.
sp.stage: RIBIERE enters from the doors up L., crossing MICHELE on stoop. MICHELE not descending steps, immediately withdraws as he has entered, through doors, leaving them open. RIBIERE is a trim, business-like young Frenchman, of some distinction of appearance. He wears a well-made English dark "cutaway" walking-suit, a derby hat and carries a handsome leather writing-case under his arm. The scene is quick.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Ah, Mariano! (Comes down R. C.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Monsieur Ribiere! J'espre que vous tes(He breaks off, turns on his heel toward the invisible musicians off R. and shouts.) Silenzio! (He turns again quickly to Ribiere.)

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Let us speak English. There are not so many who understand. (Both speak with a slight accent.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: I hope Monsieur still occupy the exalt' position of secretar' to Monseigneur the Grand Duke.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.stage: (sits R. C. and opens writing case, answers gravely).
sp.p: We will not mention the name or rank of my employer.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (at table, with gesture and accent of despair).
sp.p: Again incognito! Every year he come to our hotel for two, three day, but always incognito. (He finishes setting the table.) We lose the honor to have it known.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: He comes in his automobile from Naples. Everything is to be as on my employer's former visitsstrictly incognito. It is understood everyone shall address him as Herr von Grllerhagen

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Herr von Grllerhagen

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: He wishes to be thought a German. (Takes a notebook from case).

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Such a man! of caprice? Excentrique? (as if answering it) Ha!

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: You have said it. Last night he talked by chance to a singular North American in the hotel at Napoli. To-day he has that stranger for companion in the automobile. I remonstrate. What use? He laugh for half an hour! (Makes a gesture of humorous desperation and closes the writing case with a snap, leaving notebook outside of it.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: He is not like those cousin of his at St. Petersburgh an' Moscowa. An' yet though Monseigneur is so good an' generoso, will not the anarchist strike against the name of royalty himself? You have not the fear?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: I have. He has not. (Opens notebook.) I take what precaution I can secretly from him. You have few guests?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: It is so early in the season. Those poor musician' (nodding off R.) they wait always at every gate, to play when they see anyone coming. There is only seex peoples in the 'ole house! All of one party.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: Good! Who are they?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: There is Milor, an English Excellencythe Earl of Hawcastle; there is his son, the Excellency Honorabile Almeric St. Aubyn; there is Miladi Creeshe, an English Miladi who is sister-in-law to Milor Hawcastle.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Three English.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p:
There is an American Signorina, Mees Granger-Seempsone. Miladi Creeshe travel with her to be chaperone. (Enthusiastically.) She is young, generosa,
she give money to everyone, she is multa bella, so pretty, weeth charm

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: You speak now of Lady Creeshe?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: O, no, no, no! Miladi Creeshe is ol' lady (tapping his ears). Not hear well. Deaf. No pourboires. Nothing, I speak of the young American Lady Mees Grahnger-Seemsone who the English Honorabile son of Milor' Hawcastle wish to espouse, I think.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: Who else is there?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: There is the brother of Mees Grahnger-Seemsone, a young gentleman of North America. He make the eyes (laughing) all day at another lady who is of the party, a French lady, Comtesse de Champigny. Ha, ha! That amuse' me!

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p:
Beckoss I think Comtesse de Champigny is a such
good friend of the ole English Milor' Hawcastle. A Matre d'hotel see many things, an' I think Milor Hawcastle and Mme. de Champigny have know each other from long, perhaps. This djeuner is for them.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: And who else?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: It is all.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Good! no Russians.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: I think Milor' Hawcastle and Mme. de Champigny have been in Russia sometime.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Beckoss once I have hear them spik Russian togezzer.

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: I think there is small chance that they recognize my employer. His portrait is little known.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p:
And this North American who come in the automobiledoes
he know who he travel wiz? Does he know his Highness?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: No more than the baby which is not borned.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.stage: (looking at watch, going toward doors up L. C.).
sp.p: Set djeuner on the terrace instantly when he arrive: a perch, petit pois, iced figs, tea. I will send his own caviar and vodka from the supplies I carry.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: I set for one?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: For two. He desires that the North American breakfast with him. (Pauses on stoop.) Do not forget that the incognito is to be absolute. (Exits L. U. E.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Va bene, Signore! (Puts finishing touches to table.)
sp.stage:
(Enter from wings up R. near balustrade, Lord Hawcastle. He is a well-preserved man of fifty-six with close-clipped gray mustache and
gray hair; his eyes are quick and shrewd; his face shows some slight traces of high-living; he carries himself well and his general air is distinguished and high-bred. He is exceedingly well-groomed. Wears a suit of thinly-striped white flannel and white shoes, a four-in-hand tie of pale old-rose crepe, a Panama hat with broad ribbon striped with white and old-rose of the same shade as his tie. His accent is that of an English gentleman and a man of the world, quite without affectation. He comes down R. at once upon his entrance, to chair R. of table. MICHELE enters at same time up L., with folded newspaper; comes R.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Good morning, Mariano!

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Milor' Hawcastle is serve. (Takes Hawcastle's hat and places it upon a stool behind table.)

sp.speaker: MICHELE
sp.stage: (hands Haw newspaper from under his arm.)
sp.p: Il Mattino, the morning journal from Napoli, Milor'.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: No English papers?

sp.speaker: MICHELE.
sp.p: Milor', the mail is late. (Exit up L.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: And Madame de Champigny?

div2.stage: (MARIANO serves coffee, etc.)

(As HAWCASTLE speaks the COMTESSE DE CHAMPIGNY enters from hotel through doors up L. She is a pretty French woman of thirty-two. Wears a fashionable summer Parisian morning dress, light and gay in color, a short-sleeved little Empire jacket and long gloves. She carries a parasol. Her elaborately dressed hair is surmounted by a jaunty Parisian toque.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (lifting her hand gaily as she enters, and striking a little attitude before she descends the steps).
sp.p: Me voici!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My esteemed relative is still asleep?

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (speaking gaily, with a very slight accent, as she crosses to chair L. of table).
sp.p: I trust your beautiful son has found much better employmentas our hearts would wish him to.

div2.stage: (She gives MARIANO her parasol; he places it beside HAWCASTLE'S hat.)

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: He has. He's off on a canter with the little American, thank God!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Bravo! (She turns the hands of her gloves back and sips coffee, MARIANO serving.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: But I didn' mean Almeric. I meant my august sister-in-law. (He reads paper, puzzlingly.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: The amiable Lady Victoria Hermione Trevylan Creesh has djeuner in her apartment. What you find to read?

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: I'm such a duffer at Italian, but apparently the people along the coast are having a scare over an escaped convicta Russian.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (starting slightly, drops a spoon noisily upon a plate on the table).
sp.p: Pardon, Milor'!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: A Russian? (Her voice is quiet, but shows a faint alarm.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: "An escaped Russian bandit has been traced to Castellamare" (Pauses.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Castellamarenot twelve kilometres from here!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: "and a confidential agent"(looking up)secret service man, I dare say, "has requested his arrest. But the brigand tore himself"(repeating slowly)"tore himself"What the deuce does that mean? (Puzzles over paper.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Pardon, Milor'if I might

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Quite right, Mariano! (Handing him paper.) Translate for us.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (reading rapidly, but with growing agitation which he tries to conceal).
sp.p: "The brigan' tore himself from the hands of the carabiniere and without the doubts he conceal himself in some of those grotto near Sorrento and searchment is being execute. The agent of the Russian embassy have inform' the bureau that this escaped one is a mos' in-fay-mose robber and danger brigand."

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: What name does the journal say he has?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: It has not to say. That is all. Will Milor' and Mme, la Comtesse excuse me? And may I take the journal? (He pronounces "journal" as does Mme. de C., in the French manner.) There is one who should see it.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Thank you, Milor'! (Bows hastily and hurries out up L.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: I should like much to know his name.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: You may be sure it isn't Ivanoff.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: How can one know it is not (pauses and speaks the name very gravely) Ivanoff?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: He wouldn't be called an infamous brigand.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: That, my friend, may be only Italian journalism.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Pooh! This means a highwayman. (Finishes his coffee coolly) notnot an embezzler, Hlne.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (taking a deep breath and sinking back in her chair with a fixed gaze).
sp.p:
I am glad to believe it, but I care for no more to eat. I have some foolish feeling of unsafety. It
is now two nights that I dream of himof Ivanoffhad dreams for us both, my friend.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: What rot! It takes more than a dream to bring a man back from Siberia.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Then I pray there has been no more than dreams.

div2.stage:
Music of mandolins and guitars heard off R. with song "The Fisherman's Song." Enter ETHEL gaily and quickly from grove R. her face radiant. She is a very pretty American girl of twenty. She wears a light-brown linen skirted coat, fitting closely, and country riding skirt of the same material and color, with boots, a shirt-waist, collar and tie, and three-cornered hat. Carries a riding crop. She is followed by three musicians (two mandolins and a guitor), who laughingly continue the song. They are shabby fellows, two of them barefooted, wearing shabby patched velveteen trousers and blue flannel shirts open at the throat, with big black hats, old and shapeless; one of the mandolin players is somewhat better dressed than his companions,
wearing coat and shoes. ETHEL halts C. a little up, the musicians immediately halt; the better dressed one makes a low and sweeping bow before her; she takes money from her glove and gives it to him, the other two not discontinuing the song; the three immediately `bout face and go out gleefully, capering and still singing. All this as quickly as possible.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: The divine Miss Granger-Simpson. (Bowing, he remains at his chair.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (she speaks quickly and gaily but with a pronounced "English accent").
sp.p: The divinely happy Miss Granger-Simpson!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (rising, running to her and kissing her).
sp.p: Oh, I hope you mean

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: You mean you have made my son divinely happy?

div2.stage: ETHEL, as he speaks, extricates herself laughingly from Mme. de C, and crosses rapidly down L.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Is not every one happy in Sorrento(with a wave of her riding crop) even your son? (Exits laughngly and hurriedly through door facing front down L.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (going to stool behind table and getting her parasol, as HAW resumes his seat).
sp.p: Ah! that is good. Listen! (A piano sounds L. as if in the room ETHEL has just entered, breaking loudly and gaily into Chaminade's "Elevation." ETHEL'S voice heard for a moment, also, singing. She has flown to her piano. It looks well, indeed,our little surprise.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: It's time. If Almeric had been anything but a clumsy oof he'd have made her settle it weeks ago!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: You are invidious, mon ami! My affair is not settledam I a clumsy oof? (The piano grows softer.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (leaning toward her across table and speaking sharply and earnestly).
sp.p:
No, Hlne. Your little American, brother Horace,
is so in love with you, if you asked him suddenly, "is this day or night?" he would answer "It's Hlne," But he's too shy to speak. You're a woman; you can't press matters, but Almeric's a man; he can. He can urge an immediate marriage, which means an immediate setment, and a direct one.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: It will not be small, that settlement? (He shakes his head grimly; leaning back to look at her. She continues eagerly.) You have decide what sum? (He nods decidedly.) What?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: A hundred and fifty thousand pounds!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: My friend! Will she? (Turns and stares toward ETHEL'S room from where piano is still heard softly playing.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p:
Not for Almeric, but to be the future Countess of Hawcastle. My sister-in-law hasn't been her chaperon for a year for nothing. And, by Jove,
she hasn't done it for nothing, either. (He laughs grimly, moving back from table.) But she's deserved all I shall allow her.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: It was she who found these people. Indeed we might say that both you and I owe her something also. (Comes around behind table to Mme. de C.) Even a less captious respectability than Lady Creech's might have looked askance at the long friendship (kisses her hand) which has existed between us. Yet she has always countenanced us, though she must have guesseda great many things. And she will help us to urge an immediate marriage. You know as well as I do that unless it is immediate, there'll be the devil to pay. Don't miss that essential: something must be done at once. We're at the breaking pointif you like the wordsa most damnable insolvency. (He moves back to R. side of table.)

div2.stage:
Enter ALMERIC from grove R. He is a fair, fresh-colored Englishman of twenty-five, handsome in a rather vacuous way; has a short, fair mustache. He wears white duck
riding-breeches, light-tan leather riding gaiters and shoes, a riding-coat of white duck, a waistcoat light tan in shade, and a high riding-stock, the collar of which is white, the "puffed" tie, pink; a Panama hat with a fold of light tan and white silk round the crown. Carries a riding-crop.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Hello, Governor! (His voice is habitually loud and his accent is somewhat foppish, having a little of the "Guardsman" affectation of languor and indifference.) Howdy, Countess! (Drops into chair L. of breakfast tablesame which Mme. de C. has occupied, with a slight effect of sprawling.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Almeric! (Mme. de C. moves to center of table, behind it, looking keenly at ALMERIC.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Out riding a bit ago, you know, with Miss Granger-Simpson. Rippin' girl, isn't she?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Go on!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (continuing, slapping his gaiters carelessly with crop).
sp.p: Didn't stop with her, though.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: A sort of man in the village got me to go look at a bull-terrier pup. Wonderful little beast for points. Jolly luck,wasn't it? He's got a head on him

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: We'll concede his tremendous advantage over you in that respect. (Throws his cigar disgustedly into one of the coffee cups on the table.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Is that all you have to tell us?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Oh, no! She accepted me.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (drops into chair R. of table, with a long breath of relief.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Enfin! Bravo! And will she let it be soon?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: I dare say there'll be no row about that, I've made her aw'fly happy.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: On my soul, I believe you're rightand thank God you are! (Rises as he speaks and walks excitedly up C. Breaks off short as he sees Horace coming out of double doors L. Turns round and says): Here's the brotherattention now!

div2.stage: Enter HORACE from doors up L. He is a boyish-looking American of twenty-two, smooth-shaven. He wears white flannels, the coat double breasted and buttoned, the tie is light blue "puffing" fastened with a large pearl. He wears light-yellow chamois gloves, white shoes, a small, stiff English straw hat with blue and white ribbon. When he speaks it is with a strong "English accent," which he sometimes forgets. At present he is flushed and almost overcome with happy emotion. As he comes down steps MME. DE C. rushes toward him, taking both his hands.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Horace Granger-Simpson! Has your sister told you!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: She has, indeed. I assure you I'm quite overcome. (Mme. de C. dropping his hands, laughs deprecatingly, and steps back from him.) Really, I assure you.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My dear young friend, not at all, not at all. (Comes down C. with HORACE on his L., MME. DE C. on his R. ALMERIC has risen.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (fanning himself with his hat and wiping his brow).
sp.p: I assure you I am, I assure you I amit's quite overpowering,isn't it?

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Ah, poor Monsieur Horace! (She gently presses him into chair L. C. and sits besides him on his R.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: I say, don't take it that way, you know. She's very happy.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: She's worthy of itshe's worthy of it. I know she is.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My dear young man, may I plead in behalf of my son, forwellfor an immediate marriage?as soon as the rather stupid business details can be arranged. The affair is settled between the two dear young people themselves,why should not the ceremony take place in Italyeven here at Sorrento?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I'm sure I don't know why it shouldn't. Can't think why

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Just as you like, Governor, just as you like. (Throws himself down in chair at one of tea-tables L., crosses his legs, and lights cigarette.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Enchanting. (She is near table and the word is addressed to HORACE.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My son is all impatience!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Quite so!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Shall we dispose at once of the necessary little details, the various minor arrangements, thethe settlement? (Interrupts himself with a friendly laugh.) Of course, as a man of the world, of our world, you understand there are formalities in the nature of a settlement.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Quite so, of course I know, certainly, perfectly!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: We'll have no difficulty about that, my boy. (Laughing.) I'll wire my solicitor, immediately, and he'll be here within two days. If you wish to consult your own solicitor you can cable him.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Fact is I've a notion our solicitor, Ethel's man of business, that is, from Kokomo, Indiana, where our Governor lived, in fact a sort of guardian of hers, may be here almost any time.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: A sort of guardianwhat sort?

div2.stage: HAW stands C., HORACE sits L. C., MME. DE C. sits a little R. of HORACE, ALMERIC in chair L. all looking at HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I really can't say. Never saw him that I know of. You see we've been on this side so many yearsand there's been no occasion for this fellow to look us up, but he's never opposed anything Ethel wrote for; he seems to be an easy-going old chap.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: But would his consent to your sister's marriageor the matter of a settlementbe a necessity?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Oh, I dare say, but if he has the slightest sense of duty toward my sister, he'll be the first to welcome the alliance, won't he?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Then when my solicitor comes, he and your man can have an evening over a lot of musty papers and the thing will be done. Again my boy (taking HORACE'S hand), I welcome you to our family. God bless you!

div2.stage: MME. DE C. at same time, leaving her parasol in chair, turns up L. C.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I'm overpowered, you know, really overpowered. (Fans himself again and wipes his forehead.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Come, Almeric. (Aside to MME. DE C., whom he joins L C. for a moment.) Let him know it's a hundred and fifty thousand pounds. (Exit into doors up L. into hotel, followed immediately by ALMERIC.)

div2.stage: MME. DE C. at same time comes down C., HORACE turns toward her; she gives him both hands.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: My friend, I am happy for you.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Think of it, at the most a fortnight, and dear old Ethel will be the Honorable Mrs. St. Aubyn, future Countess of Hawcastle!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (lightly, at the same time withdrawing her hands and picking up her parasol from chair where she has left it).
sp.p: Yes, there is but those little arrangement over the settlement paper between your advocate and Lord Hawcastle'sbut you Americansyou laugh at such things. You are big, so big, like your country!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Ah, believe me, the great world, the world of yourself, Countess, has thoroughly alienated me.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (coming closer to him, looking at him admiringly).
sp.p: Ah, you retain one quality! You are big, you are careless, you are free. (She lays her right hand on his left arm. He takes her hand with his right hand. They stand facing each other.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p:
Well, perhaps, in those things I am American,
but in others, I fancy I should be thought something else, shouldn't I?

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: You are a debonnaire man of the great world; and yet you are still American, in that you are ab-omi-nab-ly rich. (She laughs sweetly.) The settlement, such matter as that, over which a Frenchman, an Italian, an Englishman, might hesitateyou laugh! Such matter as one-hundred-fifty thousand poundsyou set it aside; you laugh! You say "Oh, yestake it!"

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (looking front, his eyes wide with surprise, speaking slowly).
sp.p: A hundred and fifty thousand poundswhy that's seven hundred and fifty thous(He pauses, then finishes decidedly). She couldn't use the money to better advantage.

div2.stage: Enter ETHEL from, hotel, single door down L. She has one thickly bound book under her arm, another in her hand.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p:
My friend, how wise you are! (She perceives ETHEL'S entrance over HORACE'S shoulder and at
once runs to her, embraces her, and kisses her down L. crying.) Largesse, Sweet Countess of Hawcastle, Largesse! and au revoir! (Turns swiftly up L.) Adieu! I leave you with your dear brother. A rivederci. (She runs gaily out by hotel doors up L. waving her parasol to them as she goes.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Dear old sis, dear old pal! (Affectionately gives her hand a squeeze and drops it.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Isn't it glorious, Hoddy!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: The others are almost as pleased as we are. (He leans back in chair, knees crossed, hands clasped over knees and regards her proudly.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (near tea-table L. C. opens book in her hand, laying it on table open).
sp.p: This is Burke's Peerage, and this (indicating book under her arm) is Froissart's Chronicles. I've been reading it all over again,the St. Aubyns at Crecy and Agincourt (with an exalted expression), and St. Aubyn will be my name!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: They want it to be your name soon, Sis.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You're fond of Almeric, aren't you, Hoddyyou admire him, don't you?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Certainly.Think of all he represents.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Ah, yes; Crusader's blood flows in his veins. It is to the nobility that must be within him that I have plighted my troth. I am ready to marry him when they wish.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Then as soon as the settlement is arranged. It'll take about all your share of the estate, Sis, but it's worth ita hundred and fifty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What better use could be made of a fortune than to maintain the state and high condition of so ancient a house?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Doesn't it seem impossible that we were born in Indiana! (He speaks seriously as if the thing were incredible.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: But isn't it good that the pater "made his pile," as the Americans say, and let us come here when we were young to find the nobler things, Hoddy, the nobler things!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (laying his hand lightly on her shoulder).
sp.p: The nobler things,the nobler things, Sis. When old Hawcastle dies I'll be saying, quite off-hand, you know, "My sister, the Countess of Hawcastle"

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (sitting thoughtfully, placing one book on top of tea-table, interrupts).
sp.p: You don't suppose that father's friend, my guardian, this old Mr. Pike, will bewill be QUEER, do you?

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Well, the governor himself was rather raw, you know. This is probably a harmless enough old chapeasy to handle

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I wish I knew. I shouldn't like Almeric's family to think we had queer connections of any sortand he might turn out to be quite shockingly American (with slight but genuine pathos). II couldn't bear it, Hoddy.

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Then keep him out of the way. That's simple enough. None of them, except the solicitor, need see him.

div2.stage: Instantly upon this there is a tremendous though distant commotion off L. The noise of wild laughter and cheers, of the tarantla played by mandolins and guitars, also song, shouts of "Bravo Americano" and "Yanka Dooda." The noise continues and increases gradually. HORACE and ETHEL, somewhat startled at the outbreak, turn toward up L. HORACE going up steps leading to doors up L.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (as he goes up steps to door up L.).
sp.p: Must be a mob.

div2.stage: LADY CREECH, flustered and hot, enters from hotel through doors up R. She is a haughty, cross-looking woman in her sixties, with gray, elaborately dressed hair. Stout, reddish face, with rather frowning, thick gray eyebrows. Handsome and fashionable gray velvet dress. Wears gold-rimmed eyeglasses, a small bonnet, and carries in one hand a small white lace fan. Comes down G. panting and agitated; scene fast.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (going to Lady C. speaks close to her ear and loudly).
sp.p: Lady Creechdear Lady Creechwhat is the trouble?

sp.speaker: LADY CREECH.
sp.p: Some horrible people! coming to this hotel. They've made a riot in the village.

div2.stage:
Noise same as before, suddenly louder. MARIANO, immediately upon LADY CREECH'S entrance, appears in hotel doors up L., makes a quick gesture toward breakfast table down R., and withdraws. MICHELE, laughing, immediately enters by same doors, goes rapidly to table
down R., clears it, and exits through doors up L. with tray. The others pay no attention to this but continue dialogue.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: It's not a riotit's a revolution.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: One of your horrid fellow-countrymen, my dear. Your Americans are really too

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Not my Americans, Lady Creech!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Not ours, you know. One could hardly say that, could one?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p:
Oh, I say, what a go! (Enters rapidly through doors up L., comes down C., laughing, talking as he comes.) Motor car breaks down on the way here, one of the Johnnies in it, a German, discharges the chauffeur; and the other Johnny (he throws himself sprawling into chair L. C.), one
of your Yankee chaps, Ethel, hires two silly little donkeys, like rabbits, you know, to pull the machine the rest of the way here. Then as they can't make it, by Jove, you know, he puts himself in the straps with the donkeys, and proceeds, attended by the populace. Ha, Ha! I say!

div2.stage: HORACE, gloomy, comes down and sits at tea-table L.

sp.speaker: LADY CREECH
sp.p: Don't mumble your words, Almeric. I never understand people when they mumble their words.

div2.stage:
RIBIERE, who looks anxious, appears in doors up L., stands aside on the stoop for MARIANO and MICHELE, who enter and pass him with trays, fresh cloth, etc., for table down R., which they rapidly proceed to set. A valetde-chambre enters up L. following them immediately. He is a smooth-shaven man in plain black sack suit, smooth black hair, neat white bow tie. His waistcoat black, striped with red, cut high at the throat. He carries a tray with a silver dish of caviar and a bottle of Vodka. As he enters he hesitates for one moment, looking inquiringly at RIBIERE,
who motions him quickly toward MARIANO and MICHELE, and withdraws. Valet rapidly crosses to table R., sets caviar and vodka on the table, and exits up L. The others pay no attention to any of this.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (without pause and cutting off LADY C.).
sp.p: I went up to this Yankee chap, I mean to say. He was pullin' and tuggin' along, you see, don't you?and I said, "There you are, three of you all in a row, aren't you?"meanin' him and the two donkeys, Ethel, you see.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (who has been leaning close to ALMERIC to listen).
sp.p: Dreadful person!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: All he could answer was that he'd picked the best company in sight.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Impertinent! (Turns up C.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: No meanin' to it. I had him, you know, I rather think, didn't I?

div2.stage: MARIANO exits hastily doors up L., leaving MICHELE to finish setting table down R. At same time and during ALMERIC'S last speech, MME. DE C. enters and goes toward ETHEL up C. At same time HAW enters with MME. DE C., a number of folded newspapers under his arm. Simultaneously loud cheers off L. and a general renewal of the commotion intermittently, song, Margherita, shouts, cheers, etc.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Disgusting uproar!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (quickly, as she joins ETHEL up C.).
sp.p: But we know that such Americans are not of your class, cherie.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: A dreadful person, I quite fear.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (who has come down L. during MME. DE C.'s speech).
sp.p: The English papers. (Lays papers on table.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p:
I'll take the Pink `Un, Governor. I'm off. (Starts
up C., the Pink `Un under his arm. Passes ETHEL.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (detaining him. Speaks quickly, with a smile, but rather shyly).
sp.p: For a stroll, Almeric? Would you like me to go with you?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Well, I rather thought I'd have a quiet bit of readin', you know.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh! (Turns up with MME. DE C., troubled. Exit ALMERIC rapidly up L.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (down L. in chair, speaking in deep and gloomy voice).
sp.p: The Church Register!

div2.stage: (HAWCASTLE gives her paper. HORACE takes London Mail. HAW takes the Times.)

MICHELE is laying table R. ETHEL and MME. DE C. are slightly up R. C. HORACE sits R. of L. tea-table, down L. LADY C. sits L. of
R. tea-table down L. HAWCASTLE L. of table next L. of them.
Simultaneously with ALMERIC'S exit, MARIANO has entered up L. He is flustered and upset. Crosses rapidly to table R.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (unfolding his paper, speaks crossly to MARIANO as M. reaches table R.).
sp.p: Mariano, how long is this noise to continue?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: How can I know? We can do nothing.

sp.speaker: MICHELE.
sp.stage: (smilingly, looking up from table where he has continued to work).
sp.p: The people outside will not go while they think there is once more a chance to see the North American who pull the automobile with those donkeys (noise outside has grown faint and only the song is heard).

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p:
He have confuse me; he have confuse everybody. He will not be content with the djeuner till he have the hams and the eggs. (RIBIERE enters doors
up L., stands on stoop facing front. No interruption to MARIANO'S speech.) And he will have the eggs cooked only on one side, and how in the name of heaven can we tell which side?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: Garcon!

div2.stage: MICHELE and MARIANO instantly step back from table and stand at attention, facing front, like soldiers. RIBIERE exits quickly again into hotel.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Upon my soul, who's all this?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (not turning his head, replies in an awed undertone).
sp.p: It is Herr von Grllerhagen, a German gentleman, Milor'.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Man that owned the automobile, Probably made a fortune in sausages.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Nein, nein, Ribiere! 'S maclit nichts! (He enters up L. He is a portly man of forty-five, but rather soldierly than fat. His hair, pompadour, is reddish blonde, beginning to turn gray, like his mustache and large full beard; the latter somewhat "Henri IV." and slightly forked at bottom. His dress produces the effect rather of carelessness than of extreme fashion. He wears a travelling suit of light gray or brownish tweeds, or Irish homespuns, neat enough but not freshly pressed, trousers showing no crease, the coat cut in walking-coat style, with skirts, and big slanting pockets, in which he carries gloves, handkerchief, matches, and silver cigarette case full of Russian cigarettes. He wears russet shoes with tan spats, shirt, collar and cuffs of soft cheviot of light shade, four-in-hand tie, darker; on his head a tan-colored automobile cap with buttoned flaps. He is followed by RIBIERE, who is anxious and perturbed and wishes to call his attention to the item in the Neapolitan morning paper.
sp.stage: VASILI (as he enters is waving both RIBIERE and the paper aside, and is in high good humor, saying loudly):
sp.p: Vie viele zeite hab' Ich es gesagt? 'S macht nichtsbbchen! Las mich, las mich! Geh'n sie weg!

div2.stage: So speaking he has crossed to table R. RIBIERE has halted at steps leading to doors up L. and as VASILI concludes RIBIERE bows submissively, though with a gesture of protest, and exit doors up L. The group L have watched VASILI with hostility, and immediately upon the conclusion of this speech, Lady Creech speaks.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: What a dreadful person!

div2.stage: VASILI in crossing to his seat, chair R. of table R. passes behind table, but in front of MARIANO and MICHELE who bow profoundly as he passes.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (lifting his hand in curt, semi-military salute, to acknowledge the waiters' bows as he passes).
sp.p: See to my American friend.

div2.stage:
MICHELE immediately hastens off up L. into hotel. MARIANO takes cap VAS. hands him and places
it upon stool behind table. VASILI sits. In speaking VASILI employs an accent so light as to be scarcely detected.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (no pauseto Lady Creech, in her ear):
sp.p: Quite right, but take care, he speaks English.

sp.speaker: LADY CREECH.
sp.p: Many thoroughly objectionable persons do!

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (apparently oblivious to her remark, to MARIANO).
sp.p: My American friend wishes his own national dish.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (smiling deferentially, and serving VASILI to caviar).
sp.p: Yes, Herr von Grllerhagen, he will have the eggs on but one of both sides and the hams fried. So he go to cook it himself.

div2.stage:
Loud shout off L. music much louder. All startled, HORACE, ALMERIC and LADY CREECH, set
their papers down in their laps and turn towards doors up L. ETHEL and MME. DE C. come down a few steps so that they look into hotel through doors.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Ha! He return from the kitchen with those national dish.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: How horrid!

div2.stage: MICHELE backs out on stoop from doors L. laughing, carrying platter of ham and eggs.

sp.speaker: MICHELE.
sp.p: Eccentrique! He have gone to wash himself at the street fountain. (Tumult off L. reaches its height, the shouts of "Yanka Dooda" predominating.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Bravo! Bravo! (He is greeting PIKE, whom he sees, though the audience does not, just without doors L. ETHEL speaks at the same time as VASILI, looking same direction.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p:
Horrible! (She holds position until PIKE'S first speech, then with a slight gesture of repugnance,
turns up R. with MME. DE C., who shrugs her disdain. They are up-stage from the steps and PIKE on his entrance does not see them. They go to the Bath chairs up R.)

div2.stage:
PIKE enters up L. immediately on the speeches of VASILI and ETHEL. He is a youthful looking American of about thirty-five, good-natured, shrewd, humorous and kindly. His voice has the homely quality of the central states, clear, quiet, and strong, with a very slight drawl at times when the situation strikes him as humorous; often exhibiting an apologetic character of tone. He does not speak a dialect in the strict sense. His English is the United States language as spoken by the average citizen to be met on a day coach anywhere in the central states. He is clean shaven, and his hair, which shows a slight tendency to gray, is neatly parted on the left side. His brown straw hat is tall-crowned with a medium brim, the latter edged with a thin strip of black, and a narrow black ribbon around the crown. The hat, like the rest of his apparel, is neither new nor old. His shirt, "lay-down" collar and cuffs, are of white, well-laundered linen. He wears a black string tie. He wears instead of a
coat a linen (perhaps pongee) duster, extending to the knees. It is not of a fashionable cut, does not suggest an auto-wrap, but it is not unbecoming, nor does it grotesquely fail to fit him. His waistcoat, cut medium low, is of a gray mixture, neither dark nor light. His trousers are of the same material and not fashionably cut, but they fit him well and are neither baggy at the knees nor high-water. His shoes are plain black Congress gaiters and show a good shine. In brief he is just the average well-to-do but untravelled citizen that you might meet on the accommodation train between Logansport and Kokomo, Indiana. As he enters he is wiping his face after his ablutions, with a large towel, his hat pushed far back on his head. The sleeves of his duster are turned back, and his detachable cuffs are in the pocket of his duster. He comes through the doors rubbing his face with the towel, but pausing for a moment on the stoop, drops the towel from his face to dry his hands. All except VASILI and the waiters staring at him with frowns of annoyance.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.stage: (beamingly unconscious of this, surprised, and in a tone of cheerful apology, believing all the world to be as good-natured and sensible as Kokomo would be under the circumstances).
sp.p: Law! I didn't know there was folks here. I reckon you'll have to excuse me. (As he speaks he dries his hands quickly.) Here, son! (He hands the towel to MICHELE, who places it over one arm. PIKE rapidly descends steps, goes R. to table, taking chair L. of table. MICHELE holds his position on stoop until PIKE has passed him, then follows to the table and serves him, MARIANO attending VASILI. As PIKE crosses and sits, he takes cuffs from pocket of duster, adjusts them and turns down sleeves. MICHELE takes his hat.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: You're a true patriot, my friend. You allow no profane hand to cook your national dish. I trust you will be as successful with that wicked motor of mine.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Lord bless your soul, I've put a self-binder together after a pony-engine had butted it halfway through a brick deepoe! (Tucks napkin in collar of his waistcoat and applies himself to meal.)

div2.stage: HORACE and HAWCASTLE read their papers, now and then casting glances of great annoyance at PIKE. LADY CREECH lets her periodical rest in her lap, and without any abating or concealment, fixes PIKE with a basilisk glare which continues. He is unconscious of all this, his back being three-quarters to their group. MME DE C. and ETHEL sit in Bath chairs at back up R. and converse, also now and then giving signs of annoyance at PIKE.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: You have studied mechanics at the University?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: University? Law, no! On the old man's farm. (VASILI nods gravely.)

sp.speaker: HAWCASTLE
sp.p: Without any disrespect to you, my dear fellow, what terrific bounders most of your fellow-countrymen are!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Do you wonder Sis and I have emancipated ourselves?

sp.speaker: HAWCASTLE.
sp.p: Not at all, my dear lad.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Can I persuade you to accept a little of one of my own national dishescaviar?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Caviar? I've heard of it; I thought it was Rooshian.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: It is German, also. Will you not? (He motions MARIANO to serve PIKE.) MARIANO places a spoonful of caviar on a silver dish at PIKE'S right. PIKE is sitting three-fourths front.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I expect I'd never get to the legislature again if the boys heard about it. Still I reckon I'm far enough from home to take a few risks. (As he loads a fork with caviar and with a smile places it in his mouth. The smile slowly fades, his face becomes thoughtful, then grave he slowly sets the fork upon his plate, his eyes turn toward VASILI with a look both puzzled and plaintive, his mouth firmly closed, his jaw moving slightly.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I fear you do not like it. (Quickly pours vodka into a clean glass.) A few swallows of vodka will take away the taste. (Gives him the glass, which PIKE quickly and gravely accepts, drinking a mouthful in haste, VASILI watching him, sincerely concerned and troubled. PIKE swallows the vodka, quietly sets the glass down on the table, his eyelids begin to flutter, bends a look of suffering and distrust upon VASILI, slowly rises and closes his eyes, then slowly sits and opens them. Gradually a faint, distrustful smile appears on his face.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (rather hoarsely and weakly; in the voice of a convalescent).
sp.p: I never had any business to leave Indiana! (He shakes his head slowly, turning his head until his eyes meet those of LADY CREECH, and smiling but ruefully shakes his head at her as if sure of her sympathy. She snorts with indignation and turns toward HAWCASTLE and HORACE, to see if they have witnessed the outrage. PIKE fails to observe this, as he has immediately turned again to VASILI.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: I am sorry, my friend.

div2.stage: (PIKE takes another large forkful of caviar.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: But I thought you did not like the caviar.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: It's to take away the taste of the vodka.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I lift my hat to you.

sp.speaker: LADY CREECH
sp.p: The unpleasantness of travel lies in the horrid manners of the objectionable people with whom one is forced into contact.

sp.speaker: HAWCASTLE.
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: You never worked on a farm in your own country, Doc.?

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: That has been denied me.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (picking up the glass of vodka and shaking his head significantly).
sp.p:
I expect so. Talk about things to drink! Harvest time, and the women folks coming out from
the house with a two-gallon jug of ice-cold buttermilk. (Sets down the glass and whistles softly with delight. HORACE shows increasing signs of annoyance.)

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: You still enjoy those delights?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Not since I moved up to our county seat ten years ago and began to practice law. Things don't taste the same in the city.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: You do not like your city?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (not with braggadocio, but earnestly, almost pathetically, leaning forward across the table confidentially).
sp.p: Like it? Well sir, for public buildings and architecture, I wouldn't trade our State insane asylum for the worst ruined ruin in Europe,not for hygiene and real comfort.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: And your people?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: The best on earth. Out my way, folks are neighbors.

div2.stage: HORACE snaps his paper sharply. HAWCASTLE stares crossly.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: But you have no leisure class. (VASILI is looking keenly at HAWCASTLE and HORACE as he speaks.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Got a pretty good-sized colored population.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I mean no aristocracyno great old families such as we have, that go back and back to the Middle Ages.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
Well, I expect if they go back that far they might just as well set down and stay there. No sir, the poor in my country don't have to pay taxes for a lot of useless kings and earls and first grooms of the bed-chamber and second ladies in waiting, and I don't know what all. If anybody wants our money for nothin' he has to show anyway enough enough to steal it. I wonder a man like you doesn't
emigrate. (At the conclusion of this speech he unconsciously lifts the vodka glass but notices it before he drinks, and sets it down where it will be out of his reach and drinks coffee.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Your countryman seems to be rather down on us!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: This fellow is distinctly of the lower orders. We should cut him as completely in the States as here.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: I wonder you make this long journey, my friend, instead of to spend your holiday at home.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (laying down fork, and taking napkin from waistcoat).
sp.p: Holiday! Why, I never had time even to go to Niagara Falls!

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Finito! (Sets his napkin carelessly on table and lights a Russian cigarette.)

div2.stage: PIKE carefully and precisely folds his napkin, all except the waiters and VASILI observing this with amused contempt, MME. DE C. up R. pointing it out to ETHEL.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: What is it he does with his serviette?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (moving his chair back from the table slightly, as he folds napkin).
sp.p: No sir, you wouldn't catch me puttin' in any time in these old kingdoms unless I had to.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Hawcastle, can you tell me how much longer these persons intend to remain here listening to our conversation?

div2.stage: (This is the first comment heard by VASILI or PIKE since the latter's entrance. VASILI looks keenly at group L. frowning slightly. PIKE half turns to LADY CR. innocently puzzled, sets his napkin on table. MARIANO, bowing, gives him his hat, then attends VASILI, standing R. of him, holding his cap. MICHELE exits with tray up L.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Oh, it isn't thatbut it's somewhat annoying not to be allowed to read one's paper in peace.

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Quite beastly annoying!

sp.speaker: LADY CR.
sp.p: I had a distinct impression that the management had reserved this terrace for our party.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I fear we have disturbed these good people.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Do you think they mean us?

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: I fear so.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (gently, turning partly L. and meeting LADY CR.'s fiery glance with sincere amazement).
sp.p: Why we haven't done anything to 'em.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: No, my friend.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I guess there ain't any bones broken.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (quickly to HAWCASTLE. Throws down paper angrily on tea-table).
sp.p: I can't stand this. I shall go for a stroll.

div2.stage: PIKE rises. HORACE gropes for his hat, which is under the table.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I expect it's about time for me to go and find the two young folks I've come to look after. (He stands L. of chair, hat in hand, hand on chair back, facing front.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: You are here for a duty, then?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I shouldn't be surprised if that was the name for it. Yes sir, all the way from Kokomo, Indiana.

div2.stage:
ETHEL who, with MME. DE C. has just risen and advanced a step as if to come down, utters a low cry of fear, starts back slightly, then
stands still. HORACE having secured his hat, is just rising to go, drops back into his chair with a stifled exclamation of dismay. HAW lays his paper flat on table. All this instan-taneous.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: By Jove! (They all stare at PIKE.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I expect prob'ly Doc., I won't be able to eat with you this evening. You see(he pauses, somewhat embarrassed, fumbling with the top of chair back) you see I've come a mighty long ways to look after her and she, probably,that is, they'll prob'ly want me to have supper with them. (The latter part of this speech is spoken rather breathlessly, though not rapidly, and almost tremulously, and with a growing smile that is like a confession.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Do not trouble for me. Your young people, they have a villa?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No; they're right here in this hotel.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p:
I must get away! (He says this huskily, almost in
a whisper, as if to himself. His face is tense with anxiety. He crosses to R. behind PIKE.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (with a gesture of dismissal, though graciously).
sp.p: Seek them, I finish my cigarette.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Guess I better ask.

div2.stage: (HORACE is crossing, meaning to exit R.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Hey there! Can you

div2.stage: (HORACE proceeding, pays no attention.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Excuse me, son, ain't you an American? (More decidedly to MARIANO.) Waiter, tell that gentleman I'm speaking to him. (All this very quick.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: M'sieurthat gentleman speak with you.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: What gentleman?

div2.stage: (MARIANO bows toward PIKE.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I thought from your looks you must be an American.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Are you speaking to me?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I shouldn't be surprised. Ain't you an American?

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: I happen to have been born in the States.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, that was luck.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Will you kindly excuse me?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Hold on a minute! I'm looking for some Americans here and I expect you know 'emboy and girl named Simpson.

div2.stage:
HAW rises quickly at this, leaning on table and staring at PIKE. ETHEL crosses to up L. C.
to get a better look at PIKE. She is frightened. She is slightly in advance of MME. DE C. and has seized the latter's hand.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (no pause, crosses angrily to PIKE, saying).
sp.p: Is there any possibility that you mean Granger-Simpson? (His tone is both alarmed and truculent.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No, sir; just plain Simpson. Granger's their middle name. That's for old Jed Granger, grandfather on their ma's side. (He pronounces ma with the broad Hoosier accent "maw.") I want to see 'em both, but it's the girl I'm rilly looking for.

div2.stage: LADY C. rises and listens closely, her fan behind her ear.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Will you be good enough to state any possible reason why Miss Granger-Simpson should see you?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Reasonwhy, yesI'm her guardian.

div2.stage: ETHEL still behind him, lifts her hand to her forehead as if dizzy. MME. DE C. puts an arm around her. ETHEL recovers herself and stands rigidly, staring at PIKE.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, sir, Daniel Voorhees Pike, Attorney at Law, Kokomo, Indiana!

div2.stage: HORACE falls back from him in horror. HAW excited but cool, makes a quick, imperative gesture to LADY C., who majestically sweeps up to ETHEL, kisses her on the forehead in lofty pity, and sweeps out up L. MME. DE C. kisses ETHEL compassionately on cheek and follows LADY C. off. HAW follows LADY C., swiftly, to ETHEL, stands L. of her.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (hoarse with shame, to PIKE, slight pause after PIKE'S last speech).
sp.p: I will ask her if she will consent to an interview.

div2.stage:
VASILI, who has been watching keenly, makes a gesture to MARIANO, who gives him his cap,
bowing deeply. Makes a gesture for MARIANO to withdraw. MARIANO bows and exits up L. quickly.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: "Consent to an interview"(looks from HORACE to himself in puzzlement) Why, I want to talk to her.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: This shall make no difference to us, my child. Speak to him at once. (Exits up L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Don't you understand?I'm her guardian.

div2.stage: HORACE, with a desperate gesture, turns up sharply. PIKE'S eyes begin to follow him, but are arrested by VASILI, who speaks.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: When you have finished your affairs, my friend, remember my poor car yonder.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: All right, Doc., I'm kind of confused just now, but I reckon I can still put a plug back in a gear box.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I shall never hold up my head again. (She instantly makes him a sign to go and comes down L. to PIKE. HORACE hurriedly exits up L., hat down over his eyes.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Then au revoir, my friend. (Strolls off R.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (haughtily, yet with the air of confessing a humiliating truth, her eyes cast down).
sp.p: I am Miss Granger-Simpson. (She is L. and a little front of PIKE, who has been watching VASILI exit R. As she speaks he turns, lifts his hand toward her as if suddenly startled. He has not seen her until now. He stands for a moment in silence, looking at her with great tenderness and pride.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (with both wonder and pathos in his voice).
sp.p:
Why, I knew your pa from the time I was a little boy till he died, and I looked up to him more'n I ever looked up to anybody in my life, but I never thought (very slowly) he'd have a girl like you!
(She has turned slowly from him; he takes a short step nearer her.) He'd a been mighty proud if he could see you now.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Perhaps it will be as well if we avoid personal allusions.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I don't see how that's possible.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Will you please sit down?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am! (Ethel shivers at the "ma'am." He sits in chair which HORACE has occupied, still holding his hat in his hand.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: As you know, II(She stops as if almost breaking down, then, turning toward him, cries sharply.) Oh, are you really my guardian?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I've got the papers in my grip. I expect

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, I KNOW it!It is only that we didn't fancy, we didn't expect

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I expect you thought I'd be considerable older.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Not only that

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I expect you thought I'd neglected you a good deal (remorsefully), and it did LOOK like itnever comin' to see you; but I couldn't hardly manage the time to get away. You see, bein' trustee of your share of the estate, I don't hardly have a fair show at my law practice. But when I got your letter, eleven days ago, I says to myself, "Here, Daniel Voorhees Pike, you old shell-back, you've just got to take time. John Simpson trusted you with his property, and he's done more(his voice rises, but his tone is affectionate and shows deep feeling) he's trusted you to look out for her, and now she's come to a kind of jumpin'-off place in her lifeshe's thinking of gettin' married; and you just pack your grip-sack and hike out over there and stand by her!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I quite fail to understand your point of view. Perhaps I had best make it at once clear to you that I am no longer thinking of marrying.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (leaning back in his chair and smiling on her).
sp.p: Well, Lord-a-Mercy!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I mean I have decided upon it. The ceremony is to take place within a fortnight.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I declare!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: We shall dispense with all delays.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I don't know as I could rightly say anything against that. He must be a mighty nice fellow, and you must think a heap of him! (With a suppressed sigh.) That's the way it should be. (He smiles again and leans toward her in a friendly way.) And you're happy, are you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (with cold emphasis, sitting very straight in her chair).

div2.stage: PIKE'S expression becomes puzzled, he passes his hand over his chin, looks at her keenly. Then his eyes turn R. C. to the spot where HORACE has stood during their interview and he starts, as though shocked at a sudden thought.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: It ain't that fellow I was talkin' to yonder?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: That was my brother.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Lord-a-Mercy! (Recovering himself immediately and smiling.) But naturally, I wouldn't remember him. He couldn't have been more than twelve years old last time you were home. Of course I'd a known you

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: How? You couldn't have seen me since I was a child.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: From your picture (admiringly and gently). Though now I seeit ain't so much like you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You have a photograph of me?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: The last time I saw your father alive he gave me one. (Places hand in inner pocket and takes out, part way, a small photo in silver frame.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Gave it to you?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Gave it to me to look at. (Replaces photo in pocket. She has not seen it.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: And you remembered

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Remembered well enough to know me?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: It does not strike me as possible. We may dismiss the subject.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, if you'd like to introduce me to your (laughing feebly and tentatively, hesitates) to your

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: To my brother?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No, ma'amI mean to yourto the young man.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: To Mr. St. Aubyn? I think it quite unnecessary.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I'm afraid I can't see it just that way (with an apologetic laugh). I'll have to have a couple of talks with himsort of look him over so to speak. I won't stay around here spoilin' your fun any longer than I can help. Only just for that, and to get a letter I'm expectin' here from England. Don't you be afraid.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I do not see that you need have come at all. (Her lip begins to tremble.) We could have been spared this mortification.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You mean I mortify you? Why, II can't see how.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: In a hundred waysevery way. That common person who is with you

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: He ain't common. You only think so because he was with me.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: He told me his name, but I can't remember it. I call him Doc.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It doesn't matter! What does matter is that you needn't have come. You could have written your consent.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Not without seeing the young man.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: And you could have arranged the settlement in the same way.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Settlement? You seem to have settled it pretty well without me.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You do not understand. An alliance of this sort always entails a certain settlement.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'amwhen folks get married they generally settle down considerable.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Please listen. If you were at all a man of the world I should not have to explain that in marrying into a noble house I bring my dot, my dowry

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Money, you mean?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: If you choose to put it that way.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You mean you want to put aside something of your own to buy a lot and fix up a place to start housekeeping?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: No, noI mean a settlement upon Mr. St. Aubyn directly.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You mean you want to give it to him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: If that's the only way to make you understandyes.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: How much do you want to give him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: A hundred and fifty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Precisely that.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
Well, he has made you care for him! I guess he must he the Prince of the World, honey! (Thoughtfully.) He must be a great man.
(Sadly, but half humorously.) I expect you're right about me not meetin' him. I prob'ly wouldn't stack up very high alongside of a man that's big enough for you to think as much of as you do of him. (Smiling.) Why, I'd have to squeeze every bit of property your pa left you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Is it your property?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I've worked pretty hard to take care of it for you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Forgive me for saying that.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: It was unworthy of me, unworthy of the higher and nobler things that life calls me to live up to (proudly)that I shall live up to. (Crossing him to R.) The money means nothing to meI am not thinking of that. It is merely a necessary form.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Have you talked with Mr. St. Aubyn about this settlement,this present you want to make him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Not with him.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I thought not. You'll seehe wouldn't take it if I'd let you give it to him. A fine man like that wants to make his own way, of course. Mighty few men like to have fun poked at 'em about livin' on their wife's money.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, I can't make you understand. A settlement isn't a gift.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: How'd you happen to decide that just a hundred and fifty thousand pounds was what you wanted to give him.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: It was Mr. St. Aubyn's father who fixed the amount.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: His father? What's he got to do with it?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: He is the Earl of Hawcastle, the head of the ancient house.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: And he asks you for your propertyasks you for it in so many words?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: As a settlement.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: And your young man knows it?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I tell you I have not discussed it with Mr. St. Aubyn. (She crosses him to L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I reckon not! (Crosses rapidly to R. and turns.) Well, sir, do you know what's the first thing Mr. St. Aubyn will do when he hears his father's made such a proposition to you? He'll take the old man out in the back lot and give him a thrashing he won't forget to the day of his death!

div2.stage:
The roll of drums, distant, as if sounding below the cliff, bugle sounds at the same time; MARIANO and MICHELE come hurriedly from doors up L. and lean over balustrade at back
as if watching something below the cliff to R. RIBIERE enters quickly with them, takes one quick glance in same direction, and hurries off up R. PIKE and ETHEL, surprised, turn to look.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: A bandit of Russia, Mademoiselle. The soldiers think he hide in a grotto under the cliff. (Scene very fast.)

stage.hi: comes on rapidly from doors up L. carrying shotgun.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Oh, I say, fair sport, by Jove! Fair sport!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I saw him on the road herewhat's he meant for?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Think I'll have a chance to pot the beggar, Michele? (He joins MICHELE at balustrade.)

sp.speaker: MICHELE.
sp.p: No, Signore, there are two companies of carabiniere.

div2.stage: (PIKE, delighted, chuckles aloud.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Almeric!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Hallo!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I wish to present my guardian to you. (To PIKE.) This is Mr. St. Aubyn.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Hallo, though! It's the donkey man, isn't it? How very odd. (Carelessly.) You'll have to see the governor and our solicitor about the settlement, you know(Bugle sounds below, MICHELE runs off up R. ALMERIC interrupts himself.) Fair sport, fair sport! (Hurries off R.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I reckon I got here just in time!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Does that mean

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: It means I did right to come!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Do you think we shall tolerate even the hint of interference from you?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I shouldn't think there'd be the need of any. (Though very earnest, his tone is still kindly.) I should think your own good Simpson sense would do all the interfering necessary. (At the conclusion of this speech his voice becomes slightly sterner.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (suddenly giving away in a voice of pain and shame combined).
sp.p: Oh, you are awfulawful! (Crying, she goes rapidly to door down L. PIKE looks after her, his expression becoming slightly grimmer, yet filled with wonder. He turns toward R., with accent of wonder in his tone.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars for

div2.stage: As curtain descends, ETHEL, is entering door with handkerchief to her eyes. PIKE still looking off R., his sentence uncompleted.

div2.head: ACT II

stage.hi: Back drop shows green slopes of vineyards, castle, and olive orchards leading up the mountain side.

div2.stage:
At back an old stone wall seven feet high runs from up L. C. across stage to up R. This wall is almost covered with vines, showing autumn tints, crowning the crest of the wall and hanging from it in profusion. In the wall up C. is a broad green gate of the Southern Italian type, closed. From up R. a white-columned pergola runs obliquely to down R. The top of the pergola is an awning formed by a skeleton of green painted wooden strips thickly covered by entwining lemon branches bearing ripening lemons. Between the columns of the pergolathat is, to R.are glimpses of a formal Italian garden: flowers, hedges, and a broad flat marble vase on a slender pedestal, etc. Up L. a two-story wing of the hotel meets wall at the back and runs squarely across to tree-wings
up L. The wall of the hotel facing R. shows windows (not practicable), and is as short as can be made plausible, the object being to throw the building up stage as far as possible. The wall of the hotel facing audience shows open double doors near its R. corner, with windows upstairs and below all with lowered awnings. One window on upper floor as near L. extremity as possible, and yet fully visible to audience, is practicable. One window on lower floor, nearest double doors, is practicable. Boxes of flowers on the ledges of all the windows, and along base of wall to hotel a narrow strip of well-tended flowers, except where a single broad step leading to doorway interrupts it. A Venetian well L. C. with wrought-iron overwork, showing hanging chain. A marble bench down L. among shrubberies; an open touring-car down R. under the awning formed by the overhang of the pergola; bag of tools open on stage near-by, floor boards of the car removed, apron lifted. As the curtain rises, PIKE in shirt sleeves, his hands dirty, and wearing a workman's long blue blouse, buttoned at neck, is bending over I., side of engine, working and singing, at intervals whistling, "The Blue and the Gray." His hat, duster and cuffs are on the rear seat of the tonneau.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Mr. Pike!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (apparently not hearing him, hammering at a bolt head with a monkey-wrench and singing).
sp.p: One lies down at Appomattox

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (tapping ground impatiently with stick, speaks more sharply)
sp.p: Mr. Pike! (Short pause.) Mr. Pike, I wish a word with you.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Hum? (He moves to R. side of engine, regarding it intently, rubbing handle of monkey-wrench across chin as if puzzled.)

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: I wish to tell you that the surprise of this morning so upset me that I went for a long walk. I have just returned.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: "One wore clothes of gray." (Then whistles the air. Throughout this interview he maintains almost constantly an air of absorption in his work and continues to whistle and sing softly.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I have been even more upset by what I have just learned from my sister.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why, that's too bad.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: It is too badabsurdlymonstrously bad! She tells me that she has done you the honor to present you to the family with which we are forming an allianceto the Earl of Hawcastleher fiance's father

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, sir!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: To her fiance's aunt, Lady Creech

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
Yes, sir! the whole possetucky of them. (Singing
softly.) "She was my hanky-panky-danky from the town of Kalamazack!" Yes, sirthat French lady, too. (Throws a quick, keen glance at HORACE, then instantly appears absorbed in work again, singing.) "She ran away with a circus clownshe never did come backOh, Solomon Levi!" (Continues to whistle the tune softly.)

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: And she introduced you to her fianceto Mr. St. Aubyn himself.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes. sir (chuckles); we had quite a talk about shootin' in Indiana; said he'd heard of Peru, in his school history (chuckles). Wanted to come out some day he said, and asked what our best game was. I told him we had some Incas still preserved in the mountains of Indiana, and he said he'd like a good Inca head to put up in his gun-room. He ought to get one (imitating ALMERIC) oughtn't he. (Starts to work again, busily.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p:
My sister informs me that in spite of Lord Hawcastle's
most graciously offering to discuss her engagement with you, you refused.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I didn't see any need of it.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Furthermore you allege that you will decline to go into the matter with Lord Hawcastle's solicitor.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What matter?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: The matter of the settlement.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Your sister kind of let it out to me awhile ago that you think a good deal of this French widowlady. Suppose you make up your mind to take her for richer or poorerwhat's she going to give you?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Nothing! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, I thought you'd probably charge her (pauses and finishes with a slight drawl) a little, anyhow. Ain't that the way over here? (Turns to work again, humming Dolly Gray.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (after a few angry steps L. turns angrily).
sp.p: It is impossible for you to understand the motives of my sister and myself in our struggle not to remain in the vulgar herd. But can't you try to comprehend that there is an old-world society, based not on wealth, but on that indescribable something which comes of ancient lineage and high birth? (With great indignation.) You presume to interfere between us and the fine flower of Europe!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I don't know as the folks around Kokomo would ever have spoke of your father as a fine flower, but we thought a heap of him, and when he married your ma he was so glad to get herwell, I never heard yet that he asked for any settlement!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: You are quite impossible.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: The fact is, when she took him he was a poor man, but if he'd a had seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars I'll bet he'd a given it for her. (Starts to hammer vigorously, humming Dolly Gray.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: There is no profit in continuing the discussion. (Turns on his heel to L. and immediately turns again toward PIKE who is apparently preoccupied.) And I warn you we shall act without paying the slightest attention to you. (Triumphantly.) What have you to say to that, sir?

div2.stage: PIKE suddenly turns crank of engine starting a fearful uproar. Glances up mildly at HORACE. HORACE throws up hands despairingly and crosses to up L. PIKE stops engine and his voice becomes audible in singing last words of the song "Good-bye, Dolly Gray."
Enter up L., as HORACE crosses, LADY C. and ALMERIC. ALMERIC in white flannels.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (as he meets them, speaking in undertone).
sp.p: The fellow is hopeless.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (not hearing and speaking from habit, automatically).
sp.p: Dreadful person! (PIKE down R. continues his work, paying no attention.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Better let him alone till the governor's had time to think a bit. Governor's clever. He'll fetch the beggar about somehow.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (with a Parthian glance at the unconscious PIKE).
sp.p: I shan't stop in the creature's presenceI shall go up to my room for my forty winks. (Exits into hotel.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Day day, Aunt! (To HORACE.) I'm off to look at that pup again. You trust the governor.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I do, I do. It is insufferable, but I'll wait. (Goes off L.)

div2.stage:
PIKE stands for a moment, contemplating the car in some despondency. Still humming or whistling. LADY C., after a few moments, appears in wrapper at practicable secondstory
window up L. Unseen by PIKE, she pulls up the awning for a better view and drops lace curtains inside of window so as to screen herself from observation. Sits watching. Immediately upon HORACE'S exit MARIANO, flustered, enters hurriedly from, L., goes to gates up C., and fumbles with the lock. At the same time VASILI enters from L., smoking, hands in coat pockets.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: You make progress, my friend? (He saunters to Venetian well L. C., leans his back against it, facing PIKE.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Your machine's like a good many people,got sand in its gear-box. (MARIANO makes noise with the lock at gate.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Are you locking us in?

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (excitedly coming down and showing big key which he has taken from lock).
sp.p:
No, Herr von Grllerhagen, I lock someone outthat bandit who have not been capture. The carabiniere
warn us to close all gates for an hour. They will have that wicked one soon. There are two companies. (In a lower tone to VASILI.) Monsieur Ribiere has much fears.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: Monsieur Ribiere is sometimes a fool.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Monsieur, this conviet is a Russian, (VASILI waves him away somewhat curtly. Exit MARIANO L. shaking his head, carrying key with him.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Two companies of soldiers! A town marshal out my way would a had him yesterday.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My friend, you are teaching me to respect, your country, not by what you brag, but by what you do.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: How's that.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I see how a son of that great democracy can apply himself to a dirty machine, while his eyes are full of visions of one of its beautiful daughters.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Doc., there's sand in your gear-box.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You go down to the kitchen and make signs for some of the help to give you a nice clean bunch of rags.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: What is it you ask me to do?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (not noticing his tone, not looking up).
sp.p: I need some more rags.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My friend, I obey. (Makes a mock-serious bow and starts L. PIKE looking up and calling after him.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I won't leave the machine't wouldn't be safe.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: You fear this famous bandit would steal it?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Nobut there's parties around here might think it was a settlement.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Doc., that's where we're in the same fix.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Weidersehn, my friend. (Goes off L.)

div2.stage: PIKE kneels on L. footboard of machine above gear-box, begins to clean, using an old rag, singing "Sweet Genevieve." A distant shot off R.
