PIKE looks up at this, holding attitude for a second and ceasing his song. Then continues his work and music. LADY C. leans out from her window, staring off up R. with opera glasses. There is a noise at gate up C. as if some one hastily, but cautiously, tried to open it. PIKE looks up again, turns toward gate, and, after a short pause, again begins to sing and work, but very softly.

IVANOFF appears on top of wall up R. at back, as if climbing up cautiously from lane below
creeps from wall on to top of pergola and cautiously along top through the foliage to above PIKE down R. He peers over the foliage at PIKE. PIKE looks up slowly, and as slowly ceases "Sweet Genevieve," his voice fading away on a half-syllable, as he encounters IVANOFF'S gaze. Pause while they stare at each other. LADY C. observing.

IVANOFF is a thin, very fragile-looking man, not tall, of thirty-eight. His disordered hair is prematurely gray, his beard is a grizzled four-day's stubble. He is exceedingly haggard and worn, but has the face and look of a man of refinement and cultivation. He has lost his hat, his shoes and trousers are splashed with dried mud, and brambles cling to him here and there. He wears a soiled white shirt and collar, and a torn black tie, black waistcoat and trousers. Is covered with dust from head to foot, one sleeve of his shirt has been torn off at the elbow. He wears no coat.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (in a voice tremulous with tragic appeal).
sp.p: Est ce que vous tes un homme de bon coeur? Je ne suis coupable

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: There ain't any use in the world, your talkin' to me like that!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: You are an Englishman?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: That'll do for that. You come down from there!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (in a voice that lifts, almost cracks with sudden hope).
sp.p: An American?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: They haven't made me anything else yet.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Thank God for that! (He leans against the car as if exhausted.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I do. What makes you so glad about it? (Dialogue very rapid and serious, though the voices are low.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Because I have suffered in the cause your own forefathers gave their lives for. I am a Russian political fugitive, and I can go no further. If you give me up I shall not be taken alive. I have no weapon, but I can find a way to cut my throat.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Are you the ban-dit they're lookin'for?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: They call me that. Do I look like a bandit?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: How close are they?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (with despairing gesture up R. and L.).
sp.p: There!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Did they see you climb that wall?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: I think not.

div2.stage:
Loud sharp ringing at gate up C. At the sound
IVANOFF starts violently, throwing one arm up as if to shield his face from a blow.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Oh, my God! it is they! (He staggers back against the machine.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Do you know anything about gear-box plugs? (The ringing continues.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Nothing in the world.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Then you're a chauffeur all right. (Puts blouse on him.) Take a look at this one(with emphatic significance). It's underneath the machine. (Quickly sets his hands on IVANOFF'S shoulders, having forced the blouse on him, and pushes him beneath the car. All this very quick.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Subito! Subito! Vengo, Signore, Vengo!

div2.stage: PIKE at same time rapidly wipes his hands on a clean rag in the tonneau, puts on hat, cuffs, and duster, which have been lying on seat.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (running on from L. flustered, no pause).
sp.p: Corpo de St. Costanzo! Non posso essere dapertutto allo stesso tempo. Vengo, vengo! (Hastens to gateway with key, unfastening it busily. Meanwhile PIKE lights cigar, stands L. of auto, his back to it, one foot raised, the heel resting on footboard, behind him, his arm carelessly spread.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Ecco! (Throws open gate and falls back in astonishment.) Dio mio!

stage.hi: Two carabiniere, good-looking, soldierly men in the carabiniere uniform, cocked hats, white crossed belts, medium-sized black mustaches, etc., are disclosed, their carbines slung over their arms, their long cloaks thrown back. Behind the carab. stand some fishermen in red caps, dirty flannel shirts of blue or gray, trousers rolled up to the knee, also a few ragged beggars.

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Buon Giorno! (The two carab. enter briskly.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (springing forward and closing gate, calling to crowd outside).
sp.p: No, no! (Scene very fast.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Ceerchimo l'assassino Russo.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Dio mio! Non nell' Albergo Regina Margharita.

sp.speaker: SECOND CARAB.
sp.p: Avete visto un uomo scavaleare il muro?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Wishing you many happy returns, Colonel!

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: It is the robber of Russia. They think he climb the wall, the assassin. The other carabiniere, they surround all yonder(gesturing R. and L.) These two they search here. They ask you, please, have you see him climb the wall.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Ae quelcuno passato de qui?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: He say has any one go across here?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Chi costui?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: He want to know who that is.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: The new chauffeur for the machine, from Naples.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: E lo chauffeur di un illustre personaggio padrone dell' automobile.

sp.speaker: CARAB.
sp.p: Grazia, Signore. (To MARIANO.) Cerchereremo nel giardino. (Exit swiftly FIRST CARAB. R through pergola; SECOND, L.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p:
Dio mio! but those are the brave men, Signore.
Either one shall meet in a moment this powerful assassin who may take his lifes.

div2.stage: Murmur of voice from back arises, sounds of running feet and shrill whistles, and pounding on gate up C. MARIANO runs back to gate, opens it, showing excited and clamoring fishermen and beggars in the lane. They try to come in. He drives them back with napkin, which has been hanging over his arm, crying, "Vate, Vate! Devo dire al maresciallo di cacciarvi?" Stands up from gate in lane, continues business. Beggars and fishermen continue their noise in distance. He threatens. Meanwhile VASILI has entered from L., bundle of clean white rags in his hand.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Is there a new eruption of Vesuvius.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No; it's an eruption of Colonels trying to arrest a high school professor. I've got him under your car there.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I told them he's your new chauffeur.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My friend, do you realize the penalty for protecting a criminal from arrest?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: We'll be proud of the risk. (They have come down R. C. during dialogue, which is very fast. PIKE continuing, speaks in an undertone to IVANOFF at same time dashing rags into gear-box and out several times, as if cleaning it.) This man owns the car. You can trust him the same as your own father. (Wipes his hand on clean rag after throwing the others aside.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My friend, my friend! (Thrown up his hands in desperation and walks to well L. C. perturbed.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Look out, the governor's staff is coming back.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.stage: (closing gate and wiping his face with napkin).
sp.p: Lazzaroni! (At same time FIRST CARAB. enters from R. SECOND CARAB. from L.)

sp.speaker: SECOND CARAB.
sp.p: Niente!

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Niente la! (The two CARAB. cross briskly to each, other as they speak, and stand up C. conferring.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Grazia Dio! He has gone some other place!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You'll have to get a new off front tire, Doc. That one is pretty near gone. Better have Jim, here, put on the spare when he gets through.

div2.stage: THE CARAB. beckon to MARIANO and speak to him, up C.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: Do you know what you are asking me to do?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: To put on a new tire.

div2.stage: VASILI with exclamation and gesture of despair grimly tinged with, humor, goes back to L. greatly disturbed.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.stage: (at same time coming down to C. addressing PIKE with an embarrassed bow).
sp.p: The carabiniere with all excuses beg if you will command the chauffeur to step forth from the automobile.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.stage: (one foot on footboard, fore-arm across knee, speaks as if annoyed).
sp.p: No, sir; I worked on that machine myself for three hours. He's got his hands full of nuts and screws and bolts half fastened. If he lays them down now to come out I don't know how long it'll take to get them back in place. We want to get this job finished. (Continues with a plaintive uplift of voice.) This is serious. Tell them to go on up Main Street with their Knights of Pythias parade, and come around some day when we haven't got our hands full.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: I tell themyes sir. (Turns and confers with the carabiniere.)

div2.stage: PIKE at conclusion of this speech begins to throw tools into the bag. Tosses bag into the tonneau and slams the door shut.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (covering with this noise, his speech to VASILI).
sp.p: It'll be your turn in a minute, Doc; be mighty careful what you say

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Because the chauffeur have been engaged only today and have just arrived, the Carab. ask ten thousand pardons, but inquire how long he have been known to his employer. (He bows to VASILI with embarrassment.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: How long? Why he was raised on his father's farm. (He faces VASILI and stretches his arm out toward him as if for corroboration.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Oh, if that is so!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (his voice a trifle raised, to VASILI).
sp.p: It is so, ain't it DOC?

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: You have heard my friend say it.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Monseigneur graciously consents that. I reveal his incognito to the carabiniere.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: Is it necessary?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Otherwise I fear they will not withdraw; they have suspicion.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Very well, tell them. I rely upon them to preserve my incognito from all others.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Monseigneur, they will be discreet. (Goes up to CARAB. and speaks to them. PIKE at same time in low tone to IVANOFF.)
Make a noisekeep busy (then with more emphasis) but don't you unscrew anything.

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: Monseigneur, they withdraw. (The CARAB. with great deference and gravity salute VASILI. He returns the salute curtly.)

sp.speaker: FIRST CARAB.
sp.p: Mille grazias, Signore! (MARIANO throws the gate open, the two CARAB. go rapidly out gate sweeping the crowd away. MARIANO closes gate. PIKE has gone up C. attentively watching this.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You're pretty good.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: It required but the slightest diplomacy, Signore. Thank you, Signore! (Goes off L. rapidly and gaily. PIKE comes down to well, watching MARIANO off. He rests one hand on the superstructure of the well, his eyes turn for a moment to VASILI, who is R. C., showing that he is going to address him in his next speech, then turns L. again as though watching the disappearance of MARIANO admiringly.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: He must have mesmerized those militia boys.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: It is quite safe for the time.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
It's all right, old man! (Extends his hand to
IVANOFF and helps him up from beneath machine to L. side of it.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (continuing to grasp PIKE'S hand after he has risen).
sp.p: I will pray God for you all my life.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Wait till we get you plumb out of the woods.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (continuing, crossing PIKE toward VASILI who has gone to well).
sp.p: And you, sir, if I could speak my gratitude

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My American friend yonder has placed himself (slight pause) and myselfin danger of the penal code of Italy for protecting you. Perhaps you will be so good as to let us know for what we have incriminated ourselves.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: You are a Russian?

div2.stage: PIKE leans against car, VASILI at well, IVANOFF E. C.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Don't he afraidhe's only a German.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: The Italian journals call me a brigand, (laughs bitterly) inspired by the Russian legation in Rome. My name is Ivanoff Ivanovitch. (Throughout the scene IVANOFF is agitated and apprehensive.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: All right, old man!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: I was condemned in Petersburg ten years ago. I was a professor of the languages, a translator in the bureau of the Minister of Finance. I was a member of the Society of the Blue Fifty, a constitutionalist.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Good for you.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: I was able to do little for the cause though I tried.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: How did you try?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: I transferred funds of the government to the Society of the Blue Fifty. Never one rouble for myself, (Throws open his blouse and strikes himself on the breast). It was for Russia's sake,not mine! (speaks with great emotion.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: But you committed the great Russian crime of getting yourself caught.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Through treachery. There was an Englishman who lived in Petersburgh. He had contracts with the governmentI thought he was my best friend (laughs brokenly.) I had married in my student days in Parisah, it is the old story! (bitterly) I knew that this Englishman admired my wifeBut I trusted himas I trusted her, and he made my house his home. I had fifty thousand roubles in my desk to be delivered to my society. The police came to search; they found only mebut not my wife nor my English friendnor the fifty thousand roubles! I went to Siberia. Now I search for those two.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Was it they who sent the police?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: After they had taken the money and were beyond the frontier themselves. That is all I have against them.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Looks to me like it would be enough.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Then by your own confession you are an embezzler and a revolutionist.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why the man's down (seriously) you wouldn't go back on him now. (With a half chuckle.) Besides you've made yourself one of his confederates.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: Upon my soul, so I have. (Bursts into laughter and lays his hands on PIKE'S shoulders.) My friend, from my first sight of you in the hotel at Napoli, I saw that you were a great man.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What are you doing, running for Congress?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.stage: (R. to VASILI, who stands R. C. with PIKE).
sp.p:
Russia's constitution has been granted. I paid the
penalty of embezzlement for it by nine years of Siberia. Do you wish to send me back?

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.stage: (after a grave look at IVANOFF turns to PIKE again).
sp.p: I do not think that the Carabiniere went away without suspicion.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Suspicion! They will watch every exit from the hotel and its grounds. What I can do, until darkness

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why Doc's got the whole lower floor of this wingyou're his chauffeur

sp.speaker: YASILI
sp.p: I was about to suggest it. I have a room that can easily be spared to Professor Ivanoff.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p:
My friends, God bless both of you. (PIKE is on his R. VASILI on his L. As he speaks, he shakes
hands with PIKE and turns to offer his hand to VASILI, who, apparently without noticing it, goes up toward hotel.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Don't waste time talkin' about that. I shouldn't be surprised if you were hungry. (Takes him by elbow and walks him to door of hotel.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: I have had no food for a day.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: My secretary and valet de chambre will attend to Professor Ivanoff's needs. No one shall be allowed to enter his room.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: And don't you go out of it, either.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p:
He shall not,this way. (The three exit into hotel.) Immediately on their disappearance LADY CREECH'S curtains are whisked aside; she pops out of the window with the suddenness of Punch, leans far out with her head upside down, at the risk of her neck, trying to watch them even after they
have entered the hotel. She wears a wrapper. Laughter of MME. DE C. heard off L. LADY CR. waves her hand as if signalling in that direction and withdraws from window. Enter HORACE and MME. DE C. from L., he carrying her parasol and looking into her eyes. She is laughing.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Ah, but you laugh at me, chere Comtesse. (This with tender reproach.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: It is because I cannot believe you are always serious. (They are crossing toward R. walking slowly.)

div2.stage: Enter LORD HAW. from L. glances up at window, then stands up L. C. observing them.

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Serious? Like a lady to her knight of old, set me some task to prove how serious I am. (Deliriously) Anything!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.stage: (quickly, pausing up R. and turning to face him).
sp.p:
Ah, gladly! Complete those odious settlement.
Overcome the resistance of this bad man who so trouble your sweet sister!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: You promise me when it is settled that I may speak to you(becomes suddenly nervous and embarrassed) that I may speak to you

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Yesspeak to me

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Speak asas you must know I want to speakas I hardly dare

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Ah, that shall be when you please, dear friend.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Oh! (He kisses her hand, they start R. again.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Ah, youth! (They turn, startled, and halt, up R.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Ah, youth and sunshine and Italy!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Oh, I say, dear old boy! Lord Hawcastle, you're chaffing, aren't you?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (benignly lifting a hand, as if blessing them).
sp.p: Ah, youth and Italy, the blue sky, flowers, music and theerwhat is the other thing that goes with 'em? (Pauses, with a rallying look, leaving them to fill the blank; then, in a brisk tone): I am not following you, my children. But me seemed to espy a signal from the fair Hermione's windowthat she would descend.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Hawcastle!

div2.stage: Enter LADY C. somewhat flustered and still engaged in adjusting her dress.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Extraordinary and alarming performance. (HORACE and MME. DE C. listen to her. HAW close to her; she stands on step leading to the door.)

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: What was?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I was droppin' a look from my window at that dreadful American person

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Did he see you?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't mumble your words, Hawcastle.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Did he see you?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Oh, dear, no! In the first place it wouldn't have been proper; in the second, I kept behind the shade. And suddenly a tramp-looking man came right along on the top of the pergola yonder, like a monkey. Then he came down and talked to this Yankee person and the Yankee person took off his blouse and put it on the tramp and made him get under the motor-car.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Ha! (HORACE and MME. DE C. draw nearer.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Just as I tell you! And two Carabiniere came in and searched the garden. Then came that German creature who owns the car and the Carabiniere went away. Then the man came out from under the car and they took him in here.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Just here. The German creature has all of this floor.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Come away. (Takes her down C. HORACE and MME. DE C. follow closely.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: But their windows are closed.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Never mind. Did you hear anything that was said?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p:
They mumbled their words. You know I never understand people who mumble their words. But isn't it plain? The tramp is a confederate of the other two creatures. They're burglars, burglars
without a doubt in the world. They're plotting to rob the hotel. Ethel's American friend is an imposterno more a guardian than the waiter. He's a burglar.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Where did the Carabiniere come from?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: From the gate yonder. Mariano, the waiter, opened it for them and

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Did Mariano stay?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Until the Carabiniere left. How much more time are you going to waste before you send for the police?

div2.stage: (Bell at gate up C. sounds. They pay no attention.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Wait!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: You remember the journal this morning, Il Mattinothe escaped brigand

div2.stage: MARIANO enters from L. goes to gate, opens it to ALMERIC, who enters.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: That is precisely what I am remembering.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I shall go myself.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: We can do better than that!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (he has entered by the gate, coming down).
sp.p: Quite a family powwow you're havin'.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Is there anything unusual in the village?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Ra.-ther! Carabiniere all over the shopstill huntin' that bandit feller.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't mumble your words so!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Lookin' for a bandit. (She screams faintly.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Be quiet!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: He's still in this neighborhood, they think.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: What did I tell you? Now, how long

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: You shall not repeat one word of what you saw. (To ALMERIC) Almeric, find your betrothed and ask her to come here.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Oh, I don't mind, Pater! (Exits L.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Not a word of it to anybody, please. This is devilish important.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: But what's the good of it?

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p:
My dear young man, I congratulate you that you
and your sister need no longer submit to an odious dictation.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: By Jove!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: the dictation of a person who is incurring the risk of those extremely severe penalties provided by Italian law for such as abet, shelter or conceal criminals.

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: By Jove, we've got him!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: If you so choose to put it.

div2.stage: Enter PIKE briskly from hotel; comes immediately down to car.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Looks to me like it was going to clear up cold. (LADY C. haughtily stalks L.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Pike.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Howdy! (Begins touching different parts of the engine, apparently paying no attention to the others; humming again.)

div2.stage: MME. DE C. and HORACE haughtily follow LADY C.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: I will join you in a moment. (The others go off L.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Mr. Pike, it is an immense pity that there should have been any misunderstanding in the matter of your ward's betrothal.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, I wouldn't call it a misunderstanding.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: It would ill become a father to press upon the subject of his son's merits

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I don't want to talk about him with youI don't want to hurt your feelings.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Perhaps I might better put it on the ground of your ward's wishesof certain advantages of position which it is her ambition to attain.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I can't talk about it with anybody but her. (Enter MARIANO from L. with letter on tray. Goes to PIKE.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: There is another matter(PIKE stands examining envelope of letter MARIANO has given him in profound thought. HAW continues): I fear I do not have your attention. (MARIANO exits L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Go ahead!

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: There is another matter to which I may wish to call your attention.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, I'll talk about anything else with you.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: This is a question distinctly different (with a glance at the hotel, his voice grows sinister and threatening) distinctly!

div2.stage: ETHEL enters from L. Looks as if she had been crying; troubled, agitated, but controlled. She enters quickly, but stops L. C.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You wished me to come here. (Troubled voice, eyes cast down.)

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.stage: (going to her and taking her hand, speaking in courtierly, kindly tone):
sp.p: My child, I wish you to have another chat with our strangely prejudiced friend on the subject so near to all our hearts. And I wish to tell you that I see light breaking through our clouds. Even if he prove obdurate, do not be downcastall will be well,(benignly, his voice a little louder and very significant, speaking slowly) All will be well. (Turns and exits L., his voice coming back from wings in benign, fatherly tones): "All will be well!"

div2.stage: (There is a pause after the exit of HAW. PIKE stands regarding ETHEL, who does not look up at him.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
I'm glad you've come, Miss Ethel. I've got something
here I want to read to you. (He comes toward her from down R. She is L. C.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I did not come to hear you read.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: When I got your letter at home I wrote to Jim Cooley, our vice-consul at London, to look up the records of these Hawcastle folks and write to me here about how they stand in their own community.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: What's thought of them by the best citizens and so on.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You had the audacityyouto pry into the affairs of the Earl of Hawcastle!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why, I'd a done thatI wouldn't a stopped at anythingI'd a done that if it had been the Governor of Indiana himself.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You didn't consider it indelicate to write to strangers about my intimate affairs?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why, Jim Cooley's home-folks! His office used to be right next to mine in Kokomo.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: It's monstrousand when they find what you've doneOh, hadn't you shamed me enough without this?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I expect this letter'll show who ought to be ashamed. Now just let's sit down here and try to work things out together. (He above R. end of bench down L., she L. of it.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: "Work things out together!"

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I'm sorryfor you, I mean. But I don't see any other way to do it, excepttogether.(pause)Won't you?

div2.stage:
She moves slowly forward and sits at extreme L. of bench. He watches her, noticing how far she
withdraws from him, bows his head humbly, with a sad smile, then sits, not at extreme R. of bench but near it.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I haven't opened the letter yet. I want you to read it first, but I ought to tell you there's probably things in it'll hurt your feelings, sort of, mebbe.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, I haven't much of a doubt but Jim'll have some statements in it that'll show you I'm right about these people. If he's got the facts, I know he will.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: How do you know it?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Because I've had experience enough of life

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (interrupting, with a laugh at once scornful and pained).
sp.p: In Kokomo?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Yes Ma'am! there's just as many kinds of people in Kokomo as there is in Pekin, and I didn't serve a term in the legislature without learning to pick underhand men at sight. Now that Earl, let alone his havin' a bad eyehis ways are altogether too much on the stripe of T. Cuthbert Bentley's to suit me. (He opens the envelope slowly, continuing.) T. Cuthbert was a Chicago gentleman with a fur-lined overcoat that opened up a bank in our town, and when he caught the Canadian express three months later, all he left in Kokomo was the sign on the front door. That was painted on. And as for the sonbut thereI don't know as I have a call to say more. (Takes letter from envelope.) Here's the letter: read it for yourself. (Gives it to her, watches her as she reads.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p:
"Dear Dan: The Earldom of Hawcastle is one of the oldest in the Kingdom and the St. Aubyns have distinguished themselves in the forefront of English battles from Agincourt and Crecy to Sebastopol. (She reads this latter in a ringing voice and glances at him. PIKE seems puzzled and depressed. Takes off his hat and runs his hand through his hair.) The present holder of the title came into
it unexpectedly through a series of accidental deaths. He was a younger son's younger son, and had spent some years in Russia in businesswhat I do not knowunder another name. I suppose he assumed it that the historic name of St. Aubyn might not be tarnished by association with trade. He has spent so much of his life out of England that it is difficult to find out a great deal about him. Nothing here in his English record is seriously against him: though everything he has is mortgaged over its value, the entail having been broken. (ETHEL pauses and looks at PIKE who, much disturbed, rises, goes to well and leans against it.) As to his son, the Hon. Almeric, there's no objection alleged against his character. That's all I've been able to learn. (She stops reading with an air of triumphant finality, and rises with a laugh, exclaiming).
A terrible indictment! So that was what you counted on to convince me of my mistake?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes; it was!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (coming toward him, the letter held in her hand as if unconsciously).
sp.p:
Do you assert there is one word in this seriously
discreditable to the reputation of Lord Hawcastle or Mr. St. Aubyn?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: And you remember, it is the testimony offered by your own friend (scornfully) by your own detective!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, if I wanted a detective I wouldn't get Jim Cooleyat least not any more. (His attitude is thoroughly crestfallen.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I shall tell Lord Hawcastle that you will be ready to take up the matter of the settlement the moment his solicitor arrives. (She starts L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No, I wouldn't do that.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Because I won't take up the matter of settlements with him or anyone else.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Do you mean you cannot see what a humiliation your interference has brought upon you in this? (gesticulating toward him with the letter.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No; I see that plain enough.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Have you, after this, any further objections to my alliance with Mr. St. Aubyn?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: It ain't an alliance with Mr. St. Aubyn that you're after.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Then what am I (pauses and lays scornful emphasis on next word) "after"?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
You're after something there ain't anything to. (Goes nearer to her.) If I'd let you buy what you find it as empty as the morning after Judgment
want to with your money and your whole life, you'd Day. (She turns from him, smiling and superior.) You think because I'm a jay country lawyer I don't understand it and couldn't understand you! (With feeling and growing excited, crosses to car R. as he speaks.) Why, we've got just the same thing at home. There was little Annie Hoffmeyer. Her pa was a carpenter and doing well. (He begins to work half unconsciously with the machine as he talks.) But Annie couldn't get into the Kokomo Ladies' Literary Club, and her name didn't show up in the society column four or five times every Saturday morning, so she got her pa to give her the money to marry Artie Seymour, the minister's sonand a regular minister's son he is! Almost broke Hoffmeyer's heart, but he let her have her way and went in debt and bought them a little house on North Main Street. That was two years ago. (Turns to her.) Annie's workin' at the depoe candy-stand now and Artie's workin' at the hotel barin frontdrinking up what's left of the house.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: And you say you understandyou couple the name of a tippling yokel with that of a St. Aubyn,a gentleman of distinction.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Distinction?I didn't know he was distinguished.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (indicating letter with a gesture, and in ringing voice).
sp.p: His ancestors have fought with glory on every field of battle from Crecy and Agincourt to the Crimea.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: But you won't see much of his ancestors.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: He bears their name.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yesand it's the name you want. Nobody could look at you and not know it wasn't him. It's the name! And I'd let you buy it, if it would make you happyif you didn't have to take the people with it.

div2.stage: At about this point a deepening of color in the lights shows that it has grown to be late afternoon, near sunset. Orange tint in lights to R.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: The "people"?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Yes; the whole gang. Can't you see how they're counting on it? It's in their faces, in their ways!This Earl, don't you see he's counting on living on you? Do you think the son would get that settlement. Why a Terre Hut pick-pocket could get it away from him,let alone his old man! What do you think would become of the money "settlement"?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Part of it would go to the restoration of Hawcastle Hall and part to Glenwood Priory.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Glenwood Priory, oh?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: That is part of the estate where Almeric and I will live until Lord Hawcastle's death.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Then mighty little settlement would come around "Glenwood Priory"! (Speaks the name as though grimly amused and continues.) And this old ladythis Mrs. Creech you been travelling with

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Lady Creech!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: All right! Don't you think she's counting on it? And this French lady that's with them; isn't she trying to land your brother? (Quickly and with decision.) This crowd is on the track of John Simpson's money.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Silence! You have no right to traduce them. Do you place no value upon heredity, upon high birth?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Why, I think so much of it that I know John Simpson's daughter doesn't need anybody else's to help her out. (He comes toward her, looking at her with open admiration.) She's fine enough and I think she's sweet enough, and I know from the way she goes for me, that she's brave enough, to stand on her own feet!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: This is beside the point; I know exactly what I want in life (she has been somewhat moved by his last speech, is agitated, and a little breathless) and I could not change now if it were otherwise. I gave Almeric my promise, it was forever, and I shall keep it.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: But you can't; I'm not going to let you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I throw your interference to the winds. I shall absolutely disregard it. I shall marry without your consent.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Do you think they'd let you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I think you'll let me (laughing), especially after this terrible letter.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: By the way, did you finish it?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (looking at the letter, which with envelope she has continued to hold in her hand).
sp.p: I think so. (Turns the page.) Noit says "over" (she turns the sheetlooks at letter attentively for a momentlooks up, casts a quick glance of astonishment at PIKE.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, read it, please!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: It appears to concern a matter quite personal to yourself. (Embarrassed, assuming carelessness. Turns toward L. as if to leave, replacing letter in envelope.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I don't think I've got any secrets.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Please remember, I have not read anything on the last page. (Turns L. again, going.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, neither have I. (Reaching his hand for the letter.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh! (Halts, drops letter on bench simultaneously.)

div2.stage:
PIKE picks letter up and walks slowly toward R. with it, taking it from envelope. She stands looking after him with breathless amazement, far from hostile, yet half turned as if to go at once. PIKE taking letter out of envelope, suddenly turns at C. and looks back at her. At this she is flustered and starts L., but halts at sound of the Fishermen's song off
R. The sunset is deepening, lights stronger from R. golden red, the Fishermen's song begins with mandolins and guitars heard first and the four voices heard together.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Listen: those are the fishermen coming home.

div2.stage: PIKE stands in arrested attitude, not having looked at the letter. She sinks upon bench R., her head bent thoughtfully. The song beginning faintly off R. gives the effect of people passing from R. to L., the tenor solo occurring immediately as they pass nearest. At conclusion of the vocal part of song the instruments continue, more and more faintly off R., until the entrance of HAWCASTLE. Sunset effects continue and running into bluish twilight.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: It's mighty pretty, but it's kind of foreign and lonesome, too. (With a sad half-chuckle.) I'd rather hear something that sounded more like home. (A growing tremulousness in his voice.) I expect you've about forgot everything like that, haven't you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Seems funny, now; but out on the ocean, coming here, I kept kind of looking forward to hearing you sing. I knew how high your pa had had you educated in music, and, like the old fool I was, I kept thinking you'd sing for me some evening, " Sweet Genevieve" mebbe. You know itdon't you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: "Sweet Genevieve?" I used tobut it's rather old-fashioned and common, isn't it?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I expect so; I reckon mebbe that's the reason I like it so much. (With an apologetic and pathetic laugh.) Yes'm, it's my favorite. I couldn'tI couldn't get you to sing it for me before I go back homecould I?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: II think not. (PIKE turns away from her to R., downcast, letter still in his hand.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
Daniel Voorhees Pike, you'd ought to have known
it! (Sighs resignedly. Opens letter at last page and begins to read it.)

div2.stage: Enter HAWCASTLE from L. Comes in briskly and smilingly.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My dear child! (Then in an undertone to her.) You have prevailed over the heathen?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: No.

div2.stage: PIKE is standing R. gazing in petrifaction at the letter, facing front.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Then victory is to crown age instead of beauty. (Changing his tone to a more serious one.) Do not be troubled. Within ten minutes he will be as meek as a nun. (He goes a few steps L. with her, bowing, as she passes thoughtfully out L.)

div2.stage: AS ETHEL passes out L. HAWCASTLE lights a cigarette, goes slowly up C., pauses in front of window nearest door, then stands in doorway leaning against casement. Meanwhile PIKE down R. is reading from letter.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: "I am sorry old man Simpson's daughter thinks of buying a title. Somehow I have a notion that that may hit you Dan. (Poignant dismay and awe are expressed in his voice, as he continues.) I haven't forgotten how you always kept that picture of her on your desk. The old man thought so much of you I had an idea he hoped she'd come home some day and marry an American! (Brief pause.) Yours truly, Jim Cooley." (Pause.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (staring off L. speaks with a species of awed humility).
sp.p: I don't wonder she said she hadn't read it. (His face begins to light with radiant amazement.) But she had(takes a few steps toward well, gazing L.), and she didn't go awaynot right away! (His voice shakes slightly with feeling.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: My dear Pike(PIKE starts and turns, HAWCASTLE not moving nor pausing, continues), there is a certain question

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (interrupting, slowly folding letter and putting it in his inside pocket, meanwhile, speaking in his mildest tone).
sp.p: I don't want to seem rough with you, but I meant what I said. (Stage is growing darker; lights shine in the windows of the lower floor of the hotel. Shades of all the windows are drawn.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Imagining I did not mean that question

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Then it's all right.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Late this afternoon I developed a great anxiety concerning the penalty prescribed by Italian law for those unfortunate and impulsive individuals who connive at the escape or concealment (he speaks with significant emphasis and a glance at the hotel) of certain other unfortunates who may be, to speak vulgarly, wantedby the police. (PIKE regards him steadily for a moment, then turns, crosses to R., puts his right foot on footboard of the car, rests his right elbow on his knee, his chin on his hand.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You're anxious about that, are you?

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: So deeply that I ascertained the penalty for it. You may confirm my information by appealing to the nearest Carabinierestrange to say, many of them are very nearThe minimum penalty for one whose kind heart has thus betrayed him (he turns up sharply toward lighted windows of hotel, then sharply down to PIKE, his voice lifting) is two years imprisonmentthat is the least, and Italian prisons, I am credibly informed, are quite ferociously unpleasant. (Moonlight begins to fall from L., growing stronger.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, being in jail any place ain't much like an Elks' Carnival.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: There would be no escape, even for a citizen of your admirable country, if his complicity were established; especially if he happened to be (he steps back, turning significantly to glance at the lighted windows), as it were, caught in the act.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: An American caught in the act. (Turning at well to face HAW). They're not apt to be.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Alas! sometimes the sword hangs over even the most astute.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I don't see it.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p:
My dear young friend, imagine a badly wanted man appears upon the pergola here and makes an appeal of I know not what nature to one of your fellow countrymen, whofor the purposes of argumentis at work upon this car. Say that your too-amiable American concealed the fugitive under the automobile, and afterwards, with the connivance of a friend, deceives the officers of the law and shelters the criminal (pointing), say in a room of that lower suite yonder. (His voice shows growing excitement; IVANOFF'S shadow appears on shade of window nearest the door.) Imagine, for instance, that the shadow which at this moment appears on the curtain were that of the hunted manthen, would you not agree that a moderate
and reasonable request of your fellow-countryman, who had placed the criminal there, might be acceded to. (Shadow disappears.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What would be the nature of that request?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: It would concern a certain alliance, it might concern a certain settlement.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: If the request were -refused, what would the consequence be?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (sharply; he is growing more and more excited, but still retains some of his suavity).
sp.p: Two years, at least, for the American, and the friend who had been his accessory, and it would also involve the arrest of the fugitive. Altogether I should consider it a disastrous situation.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, looks like it. Would there be any way out of it for this fool countryman of mine?

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p:
Only one. He would accede to the demands I have
mentioned, or the people in possession of his secret would be compelled to allow the law to take its course. In fact, to make it certain that the law took its course. Now, what, in your opinion, would this fellow-countryman of yours do?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, it all depends upon which of my countrymen you caught. (He straightens up from well against which he has been leaning and his voice rises.) If it depended on the one I know best, he'd tell you he'd see you in hell first!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (controlling great anger, speaks loudly and huskily).
sp.p: He might not appreciate his own desperate situation.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Talk straight.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: I'd like nothing betterI'll give you till ten o'clock to-night. (Goes quickly up to L. of window, glancing at it.) If you don't give me the answer I want then-God help you! (Exits swiftly L.)

div2.stage: PIKE stands near well gazing despondently after him. Fishermen's song heard off R. very faint and distant to curtain. After a pause PIKE looks R., then quickly and quietly goes up to window nearest door. Taps with his finger nails, shade is slowly raised and window is opened by IVANOFF, who extends his arm, meanwhile standing himself cautiously screened by wall of room.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Is anybody else there?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Your friend has gonehe is dining away from the hotel. His valet de chambre is in the hall outside my door.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: You've got to come out of here.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Your friend warned me to remain.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You've got to go. Put on the coat and cap that are on that chair. (IVANOFF puts on cloak and cap from chair near window.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Wait. (PIKE turns and goes stealthily to gate, turns key in lock, opens the gate. Outside, but close to gate and facing front, stands a Carabiniere in the bright moonlight. He slowly salutes PIKE. PIKE falls back from gateway, and speaks in a warning tone and with a note of dismay.) Ohgood evening! (IVANOFF pauses in the window in a listening attitude. Picture. Song in the distance slightly louder. Curtain medium. Second curtain discloses PIKE closing gate and turning away; IVANOFF not seen, window closed and shade lowered.)

div2.head: ACT III

stage.hi: SceneLate same evening, a handsome private salon in the hotel; cabinets a gainst the walls, buhl tables, luxurious tapestried chairs, etc. Walls panelled Louis XV. style. Large double door up R. in R. wall; single door down R. in R. wall; both closed. Up L. in L. wall, handsome fireplace with fire burning. Window down L. in L. wall, with lambrequins and curtains. Up C. wide double doors, open; electric lights in sconces round the walls; not lit. The only light in the salon comes from the fire and the open doors up C., so that the room is dim. The open doors up C., however, disclose a brilliantly lit conservatory hall, which extends up stage as far as possible, showing amongst the plantspalms and oleanders in bloom, etc.one or two small coffee tables with chairs. Unseen and off L. an orchestra is playing (Pagliacci).

div2.stage:
Rise of curtain discloses PIKE sitting in dejected attitude before fire, but dimly seen. He wears black tie, collar and linen as before, black trousers, black waistcoat, cut rather low, and black frock coat"Western statesman" style
not fashionably cut, but well-fitting and graceful tightly buttoned at waist.

MARIANO passes in conservatory at back from L. to R., bearing coffee tray. LADY C. in evening gown of black velvet and lace, follows with stately tread. HORACE, in evening clothes, follows with MME. DE C. on his arm; she is in a handsome, very Parisian, decollete dress. They are deep in tender conversation.

PIKE rises, looking up toward doors as they pass. ETHEL passes L. to R. on arm of ALMERIC. She wears a pretty evening gown, ALMERIC in evening clothes; her head is bent and eyes cast down. PIKE stares at them as they pass, then goes to window down L. and looks out. Pause. HAW appears in conservatory hall at back. He seems about to pass on, but gives a swift glance toward the salon, then makes a sign toward off up R. MARIANO returns with tray. HAW signs him to put tray on small table at C. as far up toward back drop as possible. He sits, lighting cigar. HORACE and MME. DE C. return and join him at table. MARIANO pours coffee and exits L. (Music.)

PIKE throws open window and looks out. Sounds of wheels on cobble-stones without and crack of whip. Pause. PIKE closes window and turns toward doors up C. with a sigh of relief. The valet de
chambre (same dress as Act I., but wearing plain black overcoat and square-topped black derby) enters doors up C. from L., carrying a handsome carriage rug of black fur on his arm. He touches electric button on wall near door; bell, as he does so, is heard to ring off R. RIBIERE comes quickly and noiselessly from upper door R. They stand bowing at doors C. as VASILI enters from L. through conservatory. Valet immediately closes doors, and turns on light from button near door. VASILI wears overcoat trimmed with sables, silk hat, evening clothes, and white gloves; order ribbon in his buttonhole.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I'm mighty glad you've comeI've been waiting(breaks off and steps back in surprise as lights go up.) Law me! You must have been leading the grand march somewhere to-night.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (as valet takes his coat, turning to RIBIERE and speaking in undertone).
sp.p: You have telegraphed for the information?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE.
sp.p: Yes, sir. (Valet, with coat, hat, etc., exits by upper door R., followed by RIBIERE.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I have dined with an old tutor of mine. Once every year I come here to do that.

stage.hi: Valet immediately returns with tray on which are vodka and cigarettes, places on table near fire and exits.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (continuing, with brief, keen glance at PIKE).
sp.p: And you, I suppose you dined with the charming young lady, your ward, and her brother, as you expected. (He goes to fire and warms his hands.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, no, they've got' friends of their own here.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: So I have observed. (Sits by fire and sips vodka.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, I don't mind their not asking me. (With assumption of cheerfulness.) Fact is, these friends of hers are trying to get me to do something I can't do

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: You need not tell me that, my friend. I have both eyes and ears; I understand.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I wish you understood the rest, because it ain't easy for me to tell you. Doc., I'm afraid I've got you into a pretty bad hole.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Ah, that, I fear I do not understand.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I'm afraid I have. You and Ivanoff and meall three of us. This Hawcastle knows, and he knows it as well as I know you're settin' in that chair, that we've got that poor feller in yonder (pointing down R.).

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: Surely you can trust Lord Hawcastle not to mention it. He must know that the consequences for you, as well as for me, would be, to say the least, disastrous. Surely you made that clear to him.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No; he made it clear to me. Two years in jail is the minimum, and if I don't make up my mind by ten o'clock (VASILI looks at his watch) to do what he wants me to do

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: What does he want you to do?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: The young lady's father trusted me to look after her, and if I won't promise to let her pay seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars for thatwell, you've seen it around here, haven't you

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: I have observed itthat is if you refer to the son of Lord Hawcastle.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, if I don't consent to do that, I reckon Ivanoff has to go back to Siberia, and you and I to jail.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: He threatens that?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: He'll do that!

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: What do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (troubled, crossing to R. and turning, with his hands behind his back).
sp.p:
There wouldn't be any trouble about it if it was only me. That would make it easy. They could
land me for two years (swallowing painfully) or twenty. What makes it so hard is that I can't do what they want, even to let you and Ivanoff out (with serious emphasis). It ain't my money. All I can do is to ask you to forgive me, and warn you to get away before they come down on me. This feller's got me, Doc. Don't you see how it stands? Ivanoff can't get away

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: No; I think he can't.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: They've got this militia all around the place.

sp.speaker: VASILI.
sp.p: I passed through the cordon of Carabiniere as I came in.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: But you could get away, Doc. Up to ten o'clock you can come and go as you choose.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: So can you; Ivanoff is the only one who can't go. You have not thought of that?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No; and I won't think of it. But as for you

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: As for me (rings bell near door). I shall go.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: That's part of the load off my mind. I can't bear to think of the rest of it. I haven't known how to tell that poor feller in there.

div2.stage: (Valet enters from L. Bows, scene quick.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: Appellez le Monsieur la. (Valet goes to door down L., opens it, bowing slightly to IVANOFF, who appears. Valet then exits up R.)

div2.stage: Enter IVANOFF, very pale and haggard looking, dressed as in Act I., but with clothes mended and neatly brushed, hair well brushed. VASILI up C., PIKE L. C. Scene fast. IVANOFF comes in slowly and quietly, stands a few steps L. of door.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (as IVANOFF enters, speaking in the tone of a superior).
sp.p:
You may come in Ivanoff. Some unexpected difficulties
have arisen. Your presence here has been discovered by persons who wish evil to this gentleman who has. protected you. He can do nothing farther to save you unless he betrays a trust which has been left to him.

div2.stage: IVANOFF swallows painfully and looks pitifully from VASILI to PIKE.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (coming down to IVANOFF, standing before him humbly).
sp.p: It's the truth, old man. I can't do it. (IVANOFF'S head falls forward on his chest. Short pause.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (lifting his head, speaks in a low voice, tremulous, but controlled).
sp.p: I thank you for what you have tried to do for me. (Gives PIKE his hand. PIKE turns away to conceal his emotion. IVANOFF turns back to audience, his head again bowed.)

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (who in meantime has touched bell-button again near doors C., speaks sharply).
sp.p:
You have until ten o'clock. (Valet appears in
doors up R.) Mon chapeau et pardessus. (Valet exits.) In the mean time my friend believes Naples a safe place for me. (Valet returns with his coat, hat, and gloves, helps him on with coat, all very quick), and so, auf weidersehn. (Dismisses valet with gesture. Valet exits up L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (going to him and shaking hands heartily).
sp.p: Good-bye, Doc., and God bless you!

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: To our next meeting. (Exits briskly up C. As door closes behind VASILI, IVANOFF'S manner changes, showing excitement and vehemence. He goes rapidly to table near fire, picks up the cigarettes which are in a large silver open box and touches the bottle of vodka significantly.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: I thought soRussian!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (who has been closing the door from inside after VASILI, and seeing that the catch is secure, looks up).
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: That man, your friend, who calls himself Grollerhagen, is not a Germanhe is a Russiannot only that, he is a Russian noble. I see it in a hundred ways that you can not.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Whatever he is, he helped us this afternoon. I'd trust him to the bone.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
PIKE
sp.p: I know you feel mighty bad, but perhapsperhaps

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: There is no perhaps for me. There was never any perhaps after I met Helene.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Helene!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Helene was my wife, she who sent me to Siberia, she and my dear accursed English friend.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: His nameit was Glenwood. I shall not forget that name soon.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What was he doing in Russia?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: I have told you he had contracts with the ministry of finance where I met himhe supplied hydraulic machinery to the Government. Does the name Glenwood mean anything to you? Have you heard it?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (profoundly thoughtful, pauses, looking at IVANOFF sharply).
sp.p: No. (Then as if to himself.) And there must be a million Helenes in France.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p:
I prayed God to let me meet them before I was taken. But I talk too much of myself. I wish to
knowyouyou will be safe. They can do nothing to you, can they?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Oh, I'm all rightdon't worry about me.

div2.stage: (Loud knock at doors up C.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: It is the Carabiniere.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Steady. (Looks at watch.) Not yet. Go back. (Points to room down R.) We won't throw our hands into the discard until we're called. We'll keep on raising. (Exit IVANOFF door down L., PIKE closing door after him. PIKE then goes up toward doors C. Stops with preoccupied air scratches his head and slowly says.) "Helene." (Opens one of the doors; MARIANO discovered bowing without. HAWCASTLE is seen seated at table in background alone.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Miladi Creeshshe ask you would speak with her a few minutes.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: All right! Where is she?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Here, sir. (He opens other door, disclosing LADY C. standing in stately and belligerent attitude.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Come right in, ma'am!

div2.stage: LADY C. gets a slight sign from HAWCASTLE and enters. PIKE as she passes him gives HAWCASTLE a sharp glance. HAWCASTLE smiles coolly and lifts his coffee cup as if drinking to him. PIKE closes doors.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I need scarcely inform you that this interview is not of my seeking. (She sits R. C. stiffly.) On the contrary it is intensely disagreeable to me.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (turning from doors, gives her a quiet glance, saying in kindly tone).
sp.p: Don't you want to sit closer to the fire?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (glaring sidelong as he comes down L., ignoring his remark).
sp.p: My brother-in-law feels that someone well acquainted with Miss Granger-Simpson's ambitions and her inner nature should put the case finally to you before we proceed to extremities.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't mumble your words, if you expect me to listen to you.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Go on, ma'am!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: My brother-in-law has made us quite aware of the state of affairs, and we are quite in sympathy with my brother-in-law's attitude as to what should be done to you.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, and what's your idea of his attitude?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p:
If, in the kindness of our hearts, we condone your
offence, we insist upon your accession to our reasonable demands.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: By ten o'clock!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (leaning on the back of his chair).
sp.p: You say he told all of you? Has he told Miss Ethel?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: It hasn't been thought proper. Young girls should be shielded from everything disagreeable.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'am; that's the idea that got me into this trouble.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I say, this young lady who seems to be technically your ward is considered, by all of us who understand her, infinitely more my ward.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am! Go on.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: She came to me something more than a year ago

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Did you advertise?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I suppose it is your intention to be offensive.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No, ma'am; I didn't mean anything. But you see I've handled all her accounts, and her payments to you

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: We will omit tradesman-like references! What Lord Hawcastle wished me to impress on you is not only that you will ruin yourself, but put a blight upon the life of the young lady whom you are pleased to consider your ward. We make this suggestion because we conceive that you have a preposterous sentimental interest yourself in Miss Granger-Simpson.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Upon what other ground are we to explain your conduct?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: You mean that I'd only stand between her and you for my own sake?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: We can comprehend no other grounds.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I don't believe you can! (Slight pause.) But you can comprehend that I wouldn't have any hope, can't you?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: One never knows what these weird Americans hope. Hawcastle assures me you have some such idea, but my charge has studied under my instruction deportment, manners, and ideals, which have lifted her above the mere American circumstance of her birth. She has ambitions. If you stand in the way of them she will wither, she will die like a caged bird. All that was sordid about her parentage, she has cast off. We have thought that we might make something out of her.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (in a clear voice, but looking at her mildly).
sp.p: Make something out of heryes, ma'am?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Make something better of her. We offer her this alliance with a family which for seven hundred years

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Yes, ma'amCrecy and AgincourtI know.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: With a family never sullied by those low ideals of barter and exchange which are the governing impulses of your countrymen.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Seven hundred years(fumbling in coat pocket). Why, look here, Mrs. Creech (at this LADY C. half rises from her chair with a profound shudder, sinks back again; PIKE continues), I've got a letter right here (takes letter from pocket) that tells me your brother-in-law was in businessand I respect him for itonly a few years ago.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: A letter from whom? (Scene fast.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Jim Cooley, our Vice Consul in London. Jim ain't the wisest man in the world, but he seems to have this all right, and he says Mr. Hawcastle

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Mr. Hawcastle!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I can call a person Colonel or Cap. or Doc. or anything of that kind, but I just plain don't know how to use the kind of words you have over here for those things. They don't seem to fit my mouth somehow. Just let me run on my own way. I don't mean to hurt your feelings. Anyway, Jim says your brother-in-law was in business in Russia. (Up to this point he has gone on rapidly, but after the word " Russia " he pauses abruptly as if startled by a sudden thought and slowly repeats.) "In business in Russia!" (He rises.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: This is beside the point entirely!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (leaning on back of his chair and looking at her intently).
sp.p: It is the point! Now, between us, ain't Jim right? Ain't it the truth?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Since some of your vulgar American officials have been spying about

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Your brother-in-law was in business in Russiaso far, so good. (Leans upon back of chair watching her, eager, but smiling cordially.) I don't say he was peddling shoestrings on the corner or selling weinerwursts

div2.stage: (LADY C. gives a slight scream of indignation.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Probably something more hifalutin' and dignified than that. He was probably agent for a wooden butter-dish factory.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: He had contracts with the Russian Government itself!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (staggering back and recovering himself immediately, speaking sharply, but in a voice of great agitation).
sp.p: Not for miningnot for hydraulic machines!!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: And even so he protected the historic name of St. Aubyn.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: By God, I believe you!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't mumble your words!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Had he ever lived at Glenwood Priory?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Is your mind wandering? The priory belonged to Hawcastle's mother. Can you state it's connection with the subject?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: That's how he protected the historic name of St. Aubyn! That's the name he tookGlenwood! (He speaks with great excitement, but appealing to her for confirmation.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: What of that!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: God moves in a mysterious way his wonders to perform.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Oblige me by omitting blasphemous allusions in my presence. What answer are you prepared to make to Lord Hawcastle?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Tell your brother-in-law that he can have my answer in ten minutesand he can come to me here for it! I'll give it in the presence of the young lady and her brother.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Her brother,certainly! He is in perfect sympathy with our attitude. As for Miss Granger-Simpson's knowing anything of this most disagreeable affairno!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I shall not permit her to come near here. As her chaperon I refuse. We all refuse! (She sweeps up to doors C.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: All right; refuse away.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: I shall tell Lord Hawcastle

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Ten minutes from now and in this room. (He has followed her up C.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: But Miss Granger-Simpson under no condition whatever. (Sweeps out haughtily.)

div2.stage: (PIKE closes door behind her, goes quickly to electric button over mantle up R.not the same as used heretoforesits at table near fire, which is supplied with stationery, and writes hurriedly. Knock at doors up C.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Come in!

div2.stage: (Enter MARIANO.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Mariano, I want you to take this note to Miss Simpson. (Quickly enclosing note in envelope and addressing it).

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: The Mees Grahnger-Seempson?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Do you know where she is?

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: She walks on the terrace alone.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Give it to her yourselfto no one else (emphatically) and do it now. (Gives him note.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: At once, sir! (Going).

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Hurry! (Almost pushes him out of doors up C. closing door behind him. PIKE is excited but cool. His action up to this point for the most part easy and quiet, becomes quick and alert. He calls toward down R. C.)
Ivanoff!

div2.stage: (IVANOFF opens door down R. and comes out apprehensively.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Have they come?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p:
Not yet! (coming to chair down L. C. but not sitting, speaks sharply). Ivanoff, you prayed to
see your wife and your friend Glenwood before you went back to Siberia. (scene fast).

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: If that prayer is answered through me, will you promise to remember that it's my fight?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Ah! it is impossible;you wish to play with me!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Do I look playful? (A bugle sounds sharply off L.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: The Carabiniere come for me. (The two rush together to window down L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (as they reach the window, thrusting IVANOFF behind him).
sp.p: Don't show yourself!

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (looking out of window over PIKE'S shoulder).
sp.p: Look! Across the street from the lamp yonderthere by the doorsthe Carabiniere.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: They've been there since this afternoon.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: They are drawn up in company. (Turning away a step and throwing up his arms in despair). Oh, my God! they will come now!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Hold your horses! Not yet! (Shading his eyes from the light of the room with one hand). Look therewho on earthwho's that they've got with them?Why, good Lord! it's Doc! (astounded).

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p: Do you mean Herr von Grollerhagen?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: That's who I meandon't you see him?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: It is. Did I not tell you he was a Russian? He has betrayed me himself, (turning from window again) he was not satisfied that others should. (Bitterly) I knew I was in the wolf's throat here!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Don't you believe it? They've arrested poor old Doc. They got him as he went out.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: No; they speak respectfully to him. They bow to him

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: They'll be bowing to us in a minute. That's probably the way these colonels run you in. (Sharp knock on doors up C.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (excitedly urging IVANOFF to door down R).
sp.p: You wait till I call you, and remember it's my fight.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: You promise before I am taken that I shall see(As he cries out this door up C. opens and MARIANO appears.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
And don't you forget what I've been telling youyou get the sand out of that gear-box first thing to-morrow morning. (IVANOFF whose gesture has been wild, suddenly relapses to quiet; PIKE finishes):
or I'll see that you draw your last pay Saturday night.

div2.stage: (IVANOFF bows meekly and exits down R., closing door after him.)

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Miss Grahnger-Seempson!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: All right, Mariano!
sp.stage: (ETHEL enters haughtily, goes L. near fire. MARIANO exits. PIKE sees that door is closed, comes down near ETHEL and speaks in a voice that shows controlled emotion).
sp.p: I'm much obliged to you for taking my note the right way. I've got some pretty good reasons for not leaving this room. (She is icy in manner, but her hands fidget with the note he has sent her, crumpling it up.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Your note seemed so extraordinary urgent

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: It had to be. Some folks who want to see me are coming here, and I want you to see themhere. (He glances at door down R.) They'd stopped you from coming if they could.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (holding herself very straight in her chair and looking at him).
sp.p: There was no effort to prevent me.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No; I didn't give 'em time.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: May I ask to whom you refer?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: The whole kit and boodle of `em!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You are inelegant, Mr. Pike.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I ain't got time to be elegant, even if I knew how.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Do you mean that my chaperon would disapprove?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I shouldn't be surprised. I reckon the whole fine flower of Europe would disapprove. "Disapprove?"they'd sand-bag you to keep you away!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, then I can't stay. (Moves toward doors up C.).

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (as he goes nearer doors than she, speaks with ring of domination).
sp.p: Yes you can, and you will, and you've got to!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Got to! I shall not!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p:
I'm your guardian and you'll do as I say. You'll obey me this once if you never do again. (She looks at him defiantly, he faces her with determination, and continues without pause): You'll stay Here while I talk to these people, and you'll stay in spite of anything they say or do to make you go. (Slight pause: she yields and walks back to table
near fire up L. throwing note which she has crumpled in her hands on table. PIKE continues): God knows I hate to talk rough to you. I wouldn't hurt your feelings for the world, but it's come to a point where I've got to use the authority I have over you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (at table, not sitting, turns to him with a renewal of her defiance).
sp.p: Authority? Do you think

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You'll stay here for the next twenty minutes if I have to make Crecy and Agincourt look like a Peace Conference!
sp.stage: (She looks at him aghast, sinks into chair by table; he continues after very slight pause, in same tone).
sp.p:
You and your brother have soaked up a society-column notion of life over here; you're like old Pete Delaney of Terry Huthe got so he'd drink cold tea if there was a whiskey label on the bottle. They've fuddled you with labels, and you've come to where you're liable to get into big trouble and
spoil your life. I'm talking to you as the guardian your father left you and as your lawyer. It's my business to see that you know what kind of people you're dealin' with, and you'll sit there till I show you. As your guardian you'll be quit of me in a year. Personally, you'll be shut of me to-night, because I think I'm goin' to be put where I'll have to lead an indoor life, and can't come and talk to you, nor look after your property, either.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You're bullying me! I don't see why you talk so brutally to me.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Do you think I'd do it for anything but you? (Turns away immediately).

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You are odious. (Looks at him, quickly; he has turned away.) Insufferable! (She picks up the noe on table and begins to smooth it out on her knee.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Don't you think I know you despise me?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (looks up sharply, looks down again at the note which she continues to smooth out on her knee, her lip trembles; she controls her emotion, and speaks with restraint, neither harshly nor gently).
sp.p: I do not despise you; if I had staid at home, and grown up there, I should probably have been a provincial young woman playing "Sweet Genevieve" for you to-night. (PIKE gives a sharp sigh at this and turns R. She continues, lifting her voice, slightly). But my life has not been that, and you have humiliated me from the moment of your arrival here. You have made me ashamed both of you and of myself. (A note of anger comes into her voice.) And now you have some preposterous plan which will shame me again, humiliate both of us once more, before my friends, these gentlefolk.

div2.stage: (A loud noise without up C. LADY C's. voice is heard shouting.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I think the gentlefolk are here. (They both turn toward up C. Doors up C. are thrown open, LADY C. hurriedly enters, with MME. DE C. and HORACE, followed by ALMERIC.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (as she enters, coming toward ETHEL, followed by the others).
sp.p: My dear child, what are you doing in this dreadful place with this dreadful person. You must know it is improper.

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: My dear, les convenances!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Ethel; I'm extremely surprised, come away at once!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Oh, I say, you know, really, Miss Ethel! You can't stay here, you know, can you?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I'm her guardian; she's here by my authority; she'll stay by my authority.

div2.stage: (They group bustlingly L. in semicircle above ETHEL, who has not risen, and is looking at PIKE. They turn to PIKE indignantly as he speaks. At same time LORD HAW. appears in open doors up C. and bows sardonically to PIKE.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Ah, good evening, Mr. Pike! (Comes down C. smiling.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (to HAW impulsively as latter comes down).
sp.p: Lord Hawcastle, will you insist upon Ethel's leaving? It's quite on the cards we shall have a disagreeable scene here.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: I see no occasion for it; we're here simply for Mr. Pike's answer, which I believe will occasion something so different from what you call a disagreeable scene that we might describe it as a general rejoicing. (PIKE goes up to doors C. which HAW has left open. HAW down C. addresses others who are grouped L., continuing without pause.) Mr Pike, in spite of the eccentricities in which he chooses to veil himself, is a man of extremely good sense. (significantly, as he turns toward PIKE.) He knows where we stand and we know where he stands.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I reckon you're right so far.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: And his answer will be yes.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: But you're wrong (very short pause as he closes doors and turns)there!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (to HORACE, with sudden increase of seriousness, somewhat sinister, speaking quickly).
sp.p: Perhaps you are right, Mr. Granger-Simpson. Painful things may be done. Better the young lady were spared them. Take your sister away. (He motions HORACE toward the door.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: For God's sake doit may be quite rowdy.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: My dear, you positively must!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Ethel, I command you!

div2.stage: (Last three speeches almost simultaneous. ETHEL, troubled, half rises as if to go.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (coming down a few steps from door, imperiously to ETHEL).
sp.p: You stay right where you are!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Oh, I say!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (at same time with scream of indignation).
sp.p: Oh, the lynching ruffian!

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Ethel, do you mean to let this fellow dictate to you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (breathlessly and loudly, as if resistance were hopeless).
sp.p: Buthe says I must! (sinks back into her chair.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (coming down C. to HAWCASTLE, who is R. C., all the others L. C. and L.).
sp.p: You're here for an answer, you say. (PIKE speaks passionately.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Yes! (Scene sharp and fast.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: An answer to what?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: An answer to our request that you accede to the wishes of that young lady.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: And if I don't, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: Ethel, you must go!

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: This man is an Apache. (pronounced Apash.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Barbarian!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (almost without pause and continuing in same tone).
sp.p: I'll leave it to you to tell her.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: A gentleman would spare her that.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I won't! Speak out! Why do you come here sure of the answer you want?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Tut, tut! (He crosses to L. near ETHEL, leaving PIKE R. C., all the rest L. C. and L.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't mumble your words!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I'll make it even plainer than you like.

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: I protest against this.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Throw the rotter out of the window.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
This afternoon I tried to help a poor devila broken-down Russian running away from Siberia, where he'd been for nine years. (She rises, her eyes eagerly meet his, as she comes down L. C. He addresses her alone, continuing without pause.) A poor weak thing, hounded like you've seen a rat in the gutter by dogs and bootblacks. Some of
your friends here saw us bring him into this apartment; they know we've got him here now. If I don't agree to hand over you and seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars of the money John Simpson madeit means that the man I have tried to help goes back to rot in Siberia and I go to an Italian jail for two years, or as much longer as they can make it. What's more, the man whose rooms these are has already been arrested, because I wolfed him into helping me, and he goes with methat's the three of usunless I hand you and your fortune(he makes a sweeping gesture, indicating HAWCASTLE, LADY C., ALMERIC and MME. DE C. who stand together, grouped from L. C. to L.) over to them!

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Nonsense!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Quite a lunatic!
