sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Apache chameau, cornichon!

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I told you to go!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: He's getting nasty!

div2.stage: (These speeches almost simultaneous.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (lifting her hand to quiet them and stepping toward PIKE, speaks to him indignantly).
sp.p: I knew that you had only a further humiliation in store for me

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: But my dear

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Noyou need make no denial for yourselvessurely you know that that is not necessary with me. (To PIKE, haughtily.) Do you think I would believe that an English noble would stoop.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p:
Stoop! Why ten years ago in St. Petersburgh there was a poor revolutionist who, in his crazy patriotism, took government money for the cause he believed in. He made the mistake of keeping that money in his house, when this man (pointing
his hand outstretched to HAWCASTLE) knew it was there. He also made the mistake of having a wife that this man (still pointing to HAWCASTLE) coveted and stoleas he coveted and stole the money. (with a denunciatory gesture at HAWCASTLE) Oh, he made a good job of it. Don't think that to-night is the first time he has given information to the police. He did it then, and the husband went to Siberia

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: A dastardly slander!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: and he'll do it again to-night. I go to an Italian jail (he suddenly swings his outstretched hand to point to MME. DE C., continuing without pause) and by the living God, that same poor devil of a husband goes back to Siberia!

div2.stage: (MME. DE C. with an ejaculation of horror and fright staggers back.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Another such brutality on your part

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Let's throw him out.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: It's a ghastly lie! (to ALMERIC) Get the police.

div2.stage: (ALMERIC starts toward doors up C. At same time HAW and HORACE start toward PIKE threateningly.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: You came for your answer. Here it is. (ALMERIC halts) I give him up.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (as he throws open door down R. calls sharply).
sp.p: Ivanoff! (HORACE and HAW halt quickly, HAWCASTLE falling back. MME. DE C. who is down L. C. utters a slight scream at the word Ivanoff. She stares, into room R. as PIKE throws open the door, then, horrified, retreats slowly backward, L. IVANOFF appears in doorway R.

sp.speaker: HAWCASTLE
sp.p:
Damnation! (He seizes a chair as a weapon, holding it as if to defend himself. PIKE has advanced
to IVANOFF, L. of him, throws his right arm across IVANOFF'S breast, as if to prevent him from advancing farther. ETHEL and HORACE amazed L. C. LADY C. L. of them. Picture. IVANOFF lifts both clenched fists above his head, taking a step toward HAWCASTLE and MME. DE C. as if he felt the power to crush both of them in his naked hands. PIKE watching him intently as if ready to prevent violence. MME. DE C. who has been L. of HAWCASTLE, crosses in front of HAWCASTLE with a shuddering cry, not loud, falls on her knees in an attitude of fright and abasement, a pace L. of IVANOFF.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: Ivan, Oh, Mother of God, Ivan! Don't kill mene me tue pas, ne me tue pas!

div2.stage: IVANOFF shudders with weakness, trembles violently, collapses into chair, she still at his feet. IVANOFF sobbing.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Helene!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (one hand on IVANOFF'S shoulder, sternly to HORACE).
sp.p:
You keep hack, she's his wife. (To ETHEL, and
pointing to HAWCASTLE.) And that is his best friend!

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: It's a lie!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Then what are you doing with that chair?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (frantically, throwing down the chair, as he glances toward doors up C.).
sp.p: I deny itI never saw the man before in my life.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: (grimly, with a gesture toward MME. DE C.) The lady seems to recognize him.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (moving up C., going backward, his face toward IVANOFF, as if on the defensive).
sp.p: Almeric, go for the police. Call them quickly! (His voice loud and hoarse.)

sp.speaker: MME. DE C.
sp.p: NonoI can't!

div2.stage: ALMERIC who has started up C. halts uncertainly.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Pay no attention to her.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Call them inwe're ready. (To ETHEL.) But I want you always to remember, that I considered it cheap at the price.

div2.stage: ETHEL in an agony of shame turns from him. At same time MME. DE C., never taking her eyes from IVANOFF'S face, and showing great fear, moves back up to L. C. near HAWCASTLE, who has not relinquished the chair; though he lets it rest upon the floor, he keeps one hand upon it. HORACE, at end of HAWCASTLE'S last speech, has thrown open the doors up C., and stands in the conservatory hall at back, looking off R. No pause. Scene sharp and fast.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (at conclusion of PIKE'S speech to ETHEL, calling off R.).
sp.p: Tell that officer to bring his men in here!

div2.stage:
At same time VASILI enters briskly up C. from off L., passing behind ALMERIC, who does not see
him until he speaks. RIBIERE enters immediately after from same direction and touches button near door. A valet enters up R., takes VASILI'S coat and hat; no pause in dialogue for this.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.stage: (in loud clear voice as he enters).
sp.p: There will be no arrests to-night, my friends. (General sensation. ALMERIC turns, startled; IVANOFF rises; PIKE keeps hand on his shoulder. PIKE and IVANOFF down R.; VASILI, RIBIERE, and valet, R. C., MME. DE C. and HAW, L. C.; LADY C. a little up of them; HORACE and ETHEL R.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (violently to ALMERIC and sharp on VASILI'S speech).
sp.p: Do as I say. This man (meaning VASILI) goes, too.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: The officer is not there, the Carabiniere have been withdrawn. (To PIKE, gravely and rapidly.) For your sake I have relinquished my incognito.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I didn't know you had one.

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p: The man Ivanoff is in my custody.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: By whose authority? Do you know that you are speaking to the Earl of Hawcastle?

sp.speaker: RIBIERE
sp.p: More respectful, sir! You are addressing his highness, the Grand Duke Vasili of Russia.

div2.stage: HAWCASTLE falls back stricken.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Respectful! Think of what I've called him!

sp.speaker: VASILI
sp.p:
My friend, it has been refreshing. (To RIBIERE.) Ribiere, I shall take Ivanoff's statement in writing. Bring him with you. (The valet crosses to door up R. quickly, holding it open and bowing. VASILI at conclusion of his last speech turns on his heel, curtly, and goes rapidly out up R. RIBIERE at same time touches IVANOFF on shoulder, indicating that he must follow VASILI. IVANOFF
starts up with RIBIERE; as he comes up MME. DE C. shrinks back with low exclamation of fear.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: I would not touch younot even to strangle you. (With outstretched hand, pointing to HAWCASTLE.) But God will let me pay my debt to the Earl of Hawcastle. (Goes rapidly out up R. with RIBIERE. ETHEL down L. C. utters, at conclusion of IVANOFF'S speech, a low cry of horror, and leans toward HORACE as if faint. HORACE pust his arm around her.)

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.stage: (immediately, in hoarse whisper to ALMERIC, who has come L. C.)
sp.p: Go to her, you fool!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (appealingly, as he comes quickly down to ETHEL).
sp.p: Ethel!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (in a quiet but imperious voice to ALMERIC).
sp.p: You let her alone!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage:
(turning to PIKE, speaks half-brokenly, but loudly and quickly, at the same time turning from
HORACE and taking a step or two near PIKE, and looking mournfully into his eyes.)
sp.p: No; he has the right. I gave him my promise when I thought it an honor to bear his name. Now that you have shown me that it is a shame to bear it, the promise is only more sacred. The shame is not his fault. (ALMERIC coming behind her, takes her hand; her face shows great suffering; she stands facing PIKE, three-fourths turned from ALMERIC, and after very short pause finishes falteringly to PIKE.) Youyouwant me to be honorable, don't you?

div2.stage: HAWCASTLE up L. has uttered a subdued exclamation of triumph at ETHEL'S words, " The promise is only the more sacred." He seizes LADY C.'s arm, both their faces showing great reaction to triumph, as they lean forward, watching ETHEL eagerly. MME. DE C. is up L. C. near doors, her back to audience, her attitude despairing. HORACE R., watching with angry and miserable face. PIKE and ETHEL face each other, during a pause, then he turns slowly to R., while her head drops upon her breast, her face showing great suffering.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Daniel Voorhees Pike, God help you! (He sinks into a chair in an attitude of complete dejection.) You're an old fool. (Picture.)

div2.stage: CURTAIN.

div2.head: ACT IV
div2.stage: The morning of the next day. Scene same as Act I., except that large table down R. has been removed, and only one tea-table stands down L. Upon the steps leading to doors up L. is a pile of bags, hat-boxes, and rugs. HAWCASTLE, in tweed travelling suit and cap, is directing a porter who is adjusting a strap on a travelling bag. ALMERIC, in white flannels, Panama hat, carrying light stick, enters from double doors up L., smoking cigarette. Leans carelessly against balustrade at top of stoop.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Ah, Governor; see you're moving!

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: I may. (His manner is nervous, apprehensive, and wary. Porter touches cap and exits into hotel.) It depends.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Depends? Mme. de Champigny took the morning boat to Naples, and your trunks are gone. Shouldn't say that looked much like dependin'.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: It does, though, with that devilish convict

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Oh, but I say, Governor, you're not in a funk about him! You could bowl him over with a finger.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Not if he had what he didn't have last night, or I shouldn't be here to-day.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: You don't think the beggar'd be taking a shot at you?

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: I don't know what the crazy fool mightn't do.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (coming down steps and going to C.).
sp.p: But, you know, he's really quite as much in custody as you could wish. That Vasilivitch chap has got him fast enough.

div2.stage: LADY C., same costume as in Act I., enters down L., stands near L. C.; they do not notice her.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: The Grand Duke Vasili has the reputation of being a romantic fool. I don't know what moment he may decide to let Ivanoff loose.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Then I have the advantage over you, Hawcastle. He's just done it.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Got him a pardon from Russia by telegraph.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: You don't mean that!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Ethel has just told me.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: My God! (Springs forward and touches hell on wall near doors up L.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: An outrage! Our plans all so horribly upset

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: No, they're not. (Scene very sharp and fast.)

div2.stage: MARIANO appears in doorway.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Mariano, I'm off for Naples. Sharp's the word!

sp.speaker: MARIANO
sp.p: It is too late for the boat, Milor. You must drive to Castellamare for the train.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: There's a carriage waiting for me at the gate yonder (points off L.). Get these things into it quickquick! (MARIANO beckons porters from off L. Porters enter sharply and carry bags, etc., off L. Meanwhile, HAWCASTLE, without pause, continues rapidly and in excited voice, to ALMERIC and LADY CREECH, coming down a few steps L. C.) You must see it through, you mustn't let the thing fail; what's more you've got to hurry it, just as if I were here. This girl gave her word last night that she'd stick.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: But she's behaving very peculiarly this morning. Outrageously would be nearer it.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Shedding tears over this Ivanoff's story. What's more she has sent that dreadful Pike person to him with assistance.

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: What sort of assistance?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Money; I don't know how much, but I'm sure it was a lot.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: By Jove! Buying the beggar off, perhaps, to keep him from making a scandal for us.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: By God! that's what she's trying to do!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Then why do you go?

sp.speaker: HAW.
sp.p: Because I'm not sure she can, (Going to steps.) Wire me at the Bertolini, Naples. (Turning' at stoop.) This shows she means to stick.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: For the sake of her promise.

sp.speaker: HAW
sp.p: Yes, and for the sake of the name. (Exit up L. very rapidly.)

div2.stage: PIKE enters from R., stands near wings down R., looking after HAWCASTLE. He wears same trousers as in first act, with rather longish sack coat of same material; neat waistcoat, hat same as in Act I. Is smoking cigar. ALMERIC at C., looking after HAWCASTLE. LADY C. same. Short pause.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Your pa seems in a hurry.

div2.stage: LADY C. and ALMERIC turn, startled. LADY C. haughtily sweeps up and exits up L.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Oh, yes, possiblyhe's off, you knowto catch a train. He's so easily worried by trifles. (As he speaks he saunters R. They cross each other. PIKE comes to chair by small table L. C., rests his elbows on table, as he sits, and looks at ALMKRIC with a soil of chuckling admiration.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, you don't worrynot too easy; do you, son?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Oh, one finds nothing in particular this morning to bother one.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Not I. Of course Miss Ethel is standing to her promise.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (grimly, more to himself than to ALMERIC).
sp.p: Yes, she is.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: The Governor only thought it best to clear out a bit until we were certain that she manages to draw off this convict chap.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Draw him off?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: What you Americans call " affixing him," isn't it?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: "Affixing him?" Don't try to talk United States, my son. Just tell me in your own way.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: She's been giving him money, hasn't she? You took it to him yourself, didn't you? Naturally, we understood what it was for. She's trying to keep the beggar quiet.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: So that's what she sent this poor cuss the money for, was it?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Why, what other reason could there be?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Well, you know I sort of gathered it was because she was sorry for himthought he'd been wronged; but, of course, I'm stupid.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Well, ra-ther. I don't know that it was so necessary for her to hush him up, but it showed a very worthy intention in her, didn't?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Would you mind my being present when you thank her for it?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p:
Shouldn't in the least if I intended thanking her.
It simply shows she considers herself already one of us. It's perfectly plainwhy it's plain as you are. (Chuckles.)

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: And that's why you're not worrying?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Worrying? My good man, do you mind excusing me. I saw a most likely pup yesterday; I'm afraid some other chap'll snatch him up before I do. I should have taken him at once. Good morning! (Exits R., with a sprightly gait and a wave of his stick.)

div2.stage: PIKE sits gazing after him, shaking his head with half-admiring, half-sardonic chuckle. Looks front, wipes his forehead, and stares again after ALMERIC. Enter ETHEL up L. She wears a pretty morning dress and hat; her face is very sad.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I hear that Lord Hawcastle has left the hotel.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (rising, resting one hand on back of chair, speaks dryly).
sp.p: Yes; I saw him go.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: He left very quickly?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: He did seem to be forgetting the scenery.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: He was afraid of Ivanoff.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I shouldn't be surprised. (Turns up C.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Has Ivanoff followed him?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Not yet; I think he is looking for you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Why does he wish to see me? (Turns R. C.)

div2.stage: MARIANO enters up L.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Monsieur Ivanoff, to say good-bye, if Mademoiselle permit.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: That's all right, Mariano; Mademoiselle permits. (Exit MARIANO up L. quickly, PIKE goes up steps, turns, and looks across to ETHEL; she bows her head gravely in acquiescence; IVANOFF enters up L., passing PIKE.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (detaining him by placing hand on his shoulder, as the latter reaches the step below him).
sp.p: I'll say good-bye to you at your carriage outside, old man. I'll see you off. (Exit up L. after IVANOFF has quickly pressed his hand.)

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.stage: (going down R. C., bows deeply to ETHEL. He wears same coat and trousers as in Act III., white collar, cuffs, and black tie, plain Italian cloak and black felt hat; clean shaven).
sp.p: Dear, kind young lady, your guardian has known how to make me accept the help you granted. He has known how because his heart is like yours, full of goodness. I shall go to London and teach the languages. There I shall be able to repay you(hesitates as if ashamed)at least what you have given me in money.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Professor I van off, are you following Lord Hawcastle and your wife?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: My wife exists no longer for me. When I saw her last night so bitterly afraid of me I only knew that I never wished to see her again.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: But Lord Hawcastle?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: Him, I shall drag down with these hands.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: You mean you will follow him till you find him?

sp.speaker: IVANOFF.
sp.p:
No, no, no! I could not hurt his bodyI would not. The suffering of a man is herehere! (Strikes his clenched fist on his temples.) What is it he has of most value in this world? It is that name of histhat proud name. Except for that, he is poor, and that I shall destroy. I shall make his name a sounding for all that is shameful and despised, and I shall do that in his own country,
in England. He shall not go in his club, he shall not go amongst his own class, and in the streets they will point at him. His story and mine shall be madeAh, but too well known! Do not think me helpless to do that. There are Russians in London to-day who belong to my society, friends of mine not without influence, not withfiut power; the world will know that each word I say is true, and that name of which he and all his family have been so proud, it shall be disgrace and dishonor to bear.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Already it is that.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: But I forget myself. You think, perhaps, I am revengeful, wickedI talk so ugly.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (sinking into chair R. C., her face turned away from him, but at the same time stretching out her hand to him).
sp.p: It is not in my heart to blame you. Your wrongs have given you the right.

sp.speaker: IVANOFF
sp.p: God bless you always! (Exit quickly up L.)

div2.stage: ETHEL sits in despairing attitude; music off R., " Fisherman's Song," mandolins and voices.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Not a centessimo for you. Go to the charitable organizations! (Appears in wings R., waving her fan admohishingly toward R., where music continues. She shouts loudly.) Go to the charitable organizations! (Comes panting to chair L. C.) Natives!
Bellissima Signora!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Ethel, I have something to tell you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Lord Hawcastle wished me to say au revoir for him.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Why didn't he say it himself?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: He was called awayurgent matters of business in London.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, I know, I know!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Though we expect to catch him by telegraph at Naples and bring him back, my dear,(benevo-lently)bring him back. (Beamingly and significantly.) Of course you know better than I how that will come outabout this convict wretch, I mean.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: It is beside the point. (Loudly and sweetly.) Lord Hawcastle wished me to tell you that now, more than ever, he hopes you will press matters with your guardian, and insist upon an immediate marriage with Almeric.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Since it must be, it had better be at once. That it is a point of honor has shaken my guardian.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p:
Naturally! Creature that he is, even he must feel
that he should atone for the frightful way in which he behaved last night. Dreadful person!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: If you please, we will not speak of him in that way. (Crosses to L. C. near tea-table, her back to LADY C.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: You mean you object to my calling that dreadful person a dreadful person?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (her back still to LADY C., in a steady voice, somewhat louder).
sp.p: I not only object to it; I will not permit it.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (beginning to tremble violently with rage and fear).
sp.p: Don't mumble your words, Ethel!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I say no one shall speak disrespectfully of my guardian in my presence.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Disrespectfully? You won't permitDo you realize that you are speaking of a person whom you, no longer ago than yesterday, yourself called a preposterous savage?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: He is the best man I everI have ever known, the wisest, truest, and bravest.

div2.stage: LADY C. screams with horror and rises.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You must understand that no one who speaks slightingly of him can continue to call herself my friend.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Do you realize that you are forbidding me, your chaperon, to use the term "dreadful person"? Upon my word, how is society to repel its vulgar invaders! I warn you that any attempt to dictate to me concerning such terms may result in my leaving my post and abandoning you.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p:
Very wellI think that may be best. (Turns back
to L. C. LADY C. screams, shows signs of hysteria and fainting. HORACE enters up L. He wears dark morning clothes, a black tie, high black ribbon round his straw hat.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Oh, that I should live to hear such ingratitude, after all I have given for youall I have sacrificed.

div2.stage: HORACE comes down L.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Do you hear what your sister says? Have I lived this long to be addressed as a servant? (She falls weeping in chair R. C.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p:
Sorry, Lady Creech, but you needn't appeal to me. I've had a most awful shaking-up, and I'm almost thinking of going back home with Mr. Pike. I rather think he's about right in his ideas. You know we abused him, not only for himself, but for his vulgar friendyet his vulgar friend turned out to be a Grand Duke(pauses with a slow, plaintive gesture), and look at what our friends turned out to be. (Speaks the last clause with
almost tragic plaintiveness. Exits moodily door facing front down L.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Both against me! Think what I have given up to form you, to introduce you, and make this brilliant match for you!

div2.stage: PIKE enters up L., stands on stoop.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: It's plain you wish me to go; you do not permit me to call your guardian a dreadful person. Why, the creature's bewitched you. Anyone hearing you would believe you thought him the archangel Michael. (Shrewishly.) Things will be different in a few days. Even if I cease to be your chaperon, I shall be your aunt, and you shall learn

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: NowMrs. Creech!

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (turns upon him with a convulsive shudder, glares at him. Explosively).
sp.p: Dreadful person! (Sweeps out quickly down L.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Forefront of battle, Crecy and Agincourt!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Ah, please don't! (She crosses him to R.).

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (looks at her with a puzzled and troubled smile. Sits by table L. C., rests elbow on table, continues to look at her, speaks quietly).
sp.p: I never did know about Mythology. Who is this archangel Michael she spoke of? Do they say anything bad about him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (down R., eyes downcast, speaks gently in a troubled voice, as if making a confession).
sp.p: No. (She turns and walks slowly to balustrade back up R. He sits as before, watching her.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (with faint quaver of feeling in his voice).
sp.p: Do they say anything very good about him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Yes. (She stands with back three-quarters to him looking down over balustrade.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: That'll be mighty sweet to remember when I'm back home again.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: When you're home again I hope you will forget everything I've ever said.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Somehow it doesn't look to me as if I very likely would.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, yes, you will! All those unkind things I've said to you

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Oh, I'll forget those easy.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p:
And the other things, too, when you're once more amongst your kind, good home folks you like so welland probably there's one among them that you'll be so glad to get back to you'll hardly know you've been awayan unworldly girl (she falters),one that doesn't need to be curedOh! of all sorts of folliesa kind girl, one who's been
always sweet to you. (Turns away from him.) I can see hershe wears a white muslin and waits by the gate for you at twilight (turns to him again)isn't she like that?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No; not like that.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: But there is some one there?some one that you've cared for?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, she's only been there in a way. I've had her picture on my desk for a good while. Sometimes when I go home in the evening she kind of seems to be there. I bought a homey old house up on Main Street, you know, it's the house you were born in. It's kind of lonesome sometimes, and then I get to thinking that she's there, sitting at an old piano, that used to be my mother's, and singing to me

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Singing "Sweet Genevieve"?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p:
Yesthat's my favorite. But then I come to and I find it ain't so, no voice comes to me, and I
find there ain't anybody but me (swallows painfully), and it's so funny that even (turns away) Jim Cooley can write me letters making fun of it.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You'll find her some dayyou'll find some one to fulfill that vision, and I shall think of you in your old house among the beech trees. I shall think of you often with her, listening to her voice in the twilight. And I shall be far away from that sensible, kindly lifekeeping the promise that I have made (falters), and living out my destiny.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: What is that destiny?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: I am bound to Almeric in his misfortune, I am bound to him by his misfortune! (She goes on with a sorrowful eagerness.) He has to bear a name that will be a by-word of disgrace, and it is my duty to help him bear it, to help him make it honorable again; to inspire him in the struggle that lies before him to rise above it by his own efforts, to make a career for himself; to make the world forget the disgrace of his father in his own triumphsin the product of his own work

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Work!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Oh, I am all American to-day. No matter how humbly he begins, it will be a beginning, and no matter what it costs me I must be by his side helping him, with all my energy and strength. Can you challenge that? Isn't it true?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I can't deny itthat's what any good and brave woman ought to feel.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: And since it has to be done, it must be done at once. I haven't seen Almeric since last night; I must see him now.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: He's not here just now. (HORACE enters down L., stands in doorway, unobserved, listening.)

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p:
I've shirked facing him to-day. He has always been so light, and gay, I have dreaded to see him bending under this blow, shamed and overcome.
Now it is my duty to see him, to show him how he can hold up his head in spite of it!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I agree, it's your duty

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: That means that youas my guardianthink I am right?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I agree to it, I said.

div2.stage: PIKE R. C. ETHEL L. C. Scene fast.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Then that must mean that you consent

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: It doesI give my consent to your marriage.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (shocked and frightened in spite of herself).
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I place it in your hands.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I protest against this. She's talking like a romantic school-girl. And I for one won't bear it and I won't allow it.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Too latehe's consented! (With a half-choked sudden sob, she runs off down L.)

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: I tell you I shall not permit her to throw herself away!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Look herewho's the guardian of this girl?

sp.speaker: HORACE.
sp.p: A magnificent guardian you are! You came here to protect her from something you thought rottennow we all know it's rotten, you hand her over! (Turns with short bitter laugh, walks up stage, comes back.) By Jove! I shouldn't be surprised if you consent to the settlement, too!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: My son, I shouldn't be surprised if I did.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: Is the world topsy-turvy? Have I gone crazy? (With accusing finger pointed at PIKE.) I'll bet my soul that'll disgust her as much as it does me!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: My son, I shouldn't be surprised if it would.

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.stage: (staring at him in astonishment, backing a step).
sp.p: By the Lord, but you play a queer game, Mr. Pike!

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Oh, I'm jest crossing the Rubicon. Your father used to have a saying: "If you're going to cross the Rubicon, cross it. Don't wade out to the middle and stand there, you only get hell from both banks." (Turns up, and stands looking off R.)

div2.stage: Enter LADY C. from down L.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Mr. Granger-Simpson, have you seen my nephew?

sp.speaker: HORACE
sp.p: No; I've rather avoided that, if you don't mind my saying so.

div2.stage: ALMERIC'S voice is heard off R., "Come along! There's a good fellow!"

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Isn't that Almeric?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am! (To HORACE.) Your sister wants to see himnow's a good time. Go ask her for me if she'll come right away.

div2.stage: HORACE, with a glance over his shoulder toward R. and a shrug, exit door down L. ETHEL almost immediately comes out. Stands near chair down L.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Is he here?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: He's here, poor fellow, shamed and overcome, bending under the blow.

div2.stage: ALMERIC heard whistling off R. ETHEL, down L., gazes with horror off R. An instant before ALMERIC enters, she turns and leans against wall facing front, down L., her back toward R.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Mariano, MarianoI say Mariano! (Enters carrying a fox terrier pup, stops R., near wings, by LADY C., continuing enthusiastically.) I say, Aunty, ain't he rippin'? Lucky I got there just as I dida bounder wanted to buy him five minutes later. (MARIANO enters from hotel.) Mariano, do you think you could be trusted to wash him?tepid water, you know, and mind he doesn't take cold, and just a little milk afterwardsnothing else but milk, you understandyou. be deuced careful, I mean to say.

sp.speaker: MARIANO.
sp.p: Very well, sir. (Quickly takes pup, crosses up L., and exits.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Almeric, really, there are more important things, you know. (PIKE comes to LADY C. and ALMERIC R.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: But you don't seem to realize I might have missed him altogether. I think I'm rather to be congratulated, you know. What?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I think so, too. (With a full-arm gesture indicating ETHEL.) I have given my consent, my son.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: And the settlement?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: I consent to the settlement alsoeverything.

div2.stage: ETHEL hears nothing of this.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (greatly relieved and overjoyed, starting toward ETHEL).
sp.p: Ethel, my dear!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: I told you it would all be plain sailing, Aunty. There was nothing to worry about.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: All shall be forgiven, my child. I am too pleased, too overjoyed in your good fortune(ETHEL droops rather drearily into chair down L.)to remember any little bickerings between us. The sky has cleared wonderfully. Everything is settled.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Yes; it's all over; my guardian has consented.

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.stage: (coming R. C.; PIKE R., watching ETHEL keenly).
sp.p: Of course I never worried about itbut I fancy it will be a weight off the Governor's mind. I'll see that a wire catches him at Naplesand he'll be glad to know what became of that arrangement about the convict fellow, too.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Almeric, I think it's noble to be brave in trouble, but

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: I say you know, you've really got me.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I mean that I admire you for your pluck, for seeming unconcerned under disgrace, but

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Disgrace? Why, who's disgracednot even the Governor, as I see it. You got that chap called off, didn't you?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p:
Why that convict chapdidn't you send him away
you bought him off, didn't you, so that he won't talk?Gave him money not to bother us?

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Why, heaven pity you! Do you think that?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Ohwhat?he wouldn't agree to be still? Oh, I say, that'll be rather a pill for the Governorhe'll be a bit worried, you know.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Don't you see that it's time for you to worry a little for yourself? That you've got to begin at once to do something worthy that will obliterate this shameto begin a careerto workto work!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: But? But I mean to say, thoughbut what for? What possible need will there be for that? Don't you see, in the first place, there's the settlement

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Settlement! You talk of settlement, now.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Settlement, certainly there's the settlement!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Why, don't you understandyou're to be the Countess of Hawcastle, aren't you?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Whyhasn't he told you?the only obstacle on earth between us was this fellow's consent to the settlement, and he's just given it.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Do you mean to say he's consented to that!

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: Why, to be surehe's just consented with his own lips, didn't you?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Don't you see, don't you hear thathe's consented? He didn't mumble his wordsdon't you hear him?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: I do and disbelieve my own ears. Yesterday, when I wanted something I thought of valueand that was a namehe refused to let me buy itto-day, when I know that that name is less than nothing, worse than nothinghe bids me give my fortune for it. What manner of man is this!And you (to LADY C. and ALMERIC), what are you that after last night, you come to me and ask a settlement?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: Certainly we dowould you expect to enter a family like this and bring nothing?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC.
sp.p: I can't see that the situation has changed since yesterday. I don't stick out for the precise amount the Governor said. If it ought to be less on account of last night, why don't think we should haggle over a few thousand pounds

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (with a cry, half of relief and half of rage).
sp.p:
Oh! That is the final word of my humiliation. I felt that you were in shame and dishonor, and, because of that, I was ready to keep my wordto stand by you, to help you make yourself into
something like a manto give my life to you. That you permitted the sacrifice was enough! Now you ask me to pay for the privilege of making itI am released! I am free! (With fire.) I am not that man's property to give away, neither my fortune nor myself.

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p: You're beside yourselfisn't this what we've been wanting all the time?

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: But slow up a bitdidn't you say you'd stick?

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Any promise I ever made to you is a thousand times cancelled. This is final! (With concentrated rage and haughtiness, turning to PIKE.) And as for younever presume to speak to me again. (Turns off to L., standing rigid and indignant.)

sp.speaker: ALMERIC
sp.p: Most extraordinary girlshe's rather dreadful, isn't she?

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.p:
Give me your arm, Almeric. (They pass behind
ETHEL haughtily and exit down L., lowest entrance.)

sp.speaker: LADY C.
sp.stage: (voice is heard from wings in a hoarse whisper).
sp.p: Dreadful person!

div2.stage: PIKE a little up stage R. Pause till they have gone.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: What have you to say to me?

div2.stage: PIKE raises his hands slowly, with palms outward, and drops them.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: What explanation have you to make?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p:
That's because you don't care what I think of you(turning to him bitterly.) Indeed you've already shown that, when you were willing to give me up to those people, and to let me pay them for taking me! You let me romanticize to you about honor and duty and sympathyabout my efforts to make that creature a manand you pretended to sympathize with me, and you
knew all the time it was only the money they were after!

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I shouldn't be surprised.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Money, money, money! I wish I had not a penny in the world.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.stage: (with a step toward her, his voice tremblng).
sp.p: I wish you hadn't!

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: Didn't you have the faint little understanding of me enough to see that their asking for money, nowwould horrify me? Didn't you know that your consenting to it, leaving me free to give it to them, would release memake me free to deny everything to them?

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Well, I shouldn't be surprised if I had seen that.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.stage: (staggeredfalling back a step, her face and attitude showing that the revelation both frightens and angers her).
sp.p:
You mean you've been saving me again from myself, from my silliness, from my romanticism, that
you've given me another revelation of the falsity, the unreality of my attitude toward these people, and toward life.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: You'd always say that, you'd always deny itit's like you. You let me make a fool of myself and then you show it to me, and after that you deny it! (Angrily.) You're always exhibiting your superiority! Would you do that to the dream girl you told me of, to the girl at home who plays dream songs for you in the empty house among the beeches? Do you think any girl could love a man for that? (She goes to door down L. The door is open.) Go back to your dream girl, your lady of the picture.

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: She won't be there.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: She might be.

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: No, there ain't any chance of that. The house will still be empty.

sp.speaker: ETHEL
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: PIKE.
sp.p: There ain't any doubt of it now.

sp.speaker: ETHEL.
sp.p: You might be wrong for once. (Very slowly enters find closes door behind her.)

sp.speaker: PIKE
sp.p: Not the time when I want to be wrong. Daniel Voorhees Pike, it would be too good for you to be wrong now. Such things ain't going to happen to youthey're too fine for youbut, thank God, you haven't been such a fool as to hope for itbecause if you had(From within hotel come sounds of piano in preliminary chords of "Sweet Genevieve," then ETHEL'S voice in the song, at first faint, somewhat tremulous and quavering, then rising strongly and confidently. PIKE rises and stands, almost appalled, by his chair, then slowly crosses the stage as one spellbound to L. of door down L., and noislessly and slowly pushes door open. He falls back a step, looking in. Curtain slow, orchestra taking up song.)
